name: Early Human Societies and the Agricultural Revolution
short_description: Students explore the transition from nomadic hunter-gatherer societies to settled agricultural communities, examining how the Neolithic Revolution transformed human civilization and led to the development of permanent settlements.

sub_topics.name: Paleolithic Era and Hunter-Gatherers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the lifestyle, tools, and survival strategies of early humans during the Old Stone Age.

sub_topics.name: Hunter-Gatherer Lifestyle and Social Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how early humans lived in small nomadic groups, their social organization, and survival methods.
example_tasks: Describe three ways Paleolithic people obtained food and explain why they needed to move frequently
Compare the daily life of a Paleolithic hunter-gatherer to your own daily life, identifying three major differences
Analyze a cave painting from Lascaux, France, and explain what it reveals about Paleolithic culture and beliefs

sub_topics.name: Paleolithic Tools and Technology
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about stone tools, weapons, and technological innovations of early humans.
example_tasks: Identify three types of Paleolithic tools and explain the purpose of each
Explain how the development of fire changed human life during the Paleolithic era
Create a timeline showing the progression of tool technology from simple stone tools to more complex implements

sub_topics.name: Neolithic Revolution and Agricultural Development
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the shift to agriculture and domestication of plants and animals, and its profound impact on human society.

sub_topics.name: Plant and Animal Domestication
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how humans began to cultivate crops and domesticate animals for food and labor.
example_tasks: Explain why the domestication of wheat and barley was significant for human civilization
Compare the advantages and disadvantages of farming versus hunting and gathering
Identify three animals domesticated during the Neolithic period and explain how each helped early farmers

sub_topics.name: Development of Permanent Settlements
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how agriculture enabled humans to establish permanent villages and towns.
example_tasks: Describe three characteristics of Neolithic settlements like Çatalhöyük in Turkey
Explain how permanent settlements led to population growth and new social structures
Analyze archaeological evidence from a Neolithic village and draw conclusions about how people lived

sub_topics.name: Social and Economic Changes from Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how agriculture led to job specialization, social classes, and economic systems.
example_tasks: Explain how surplus food production led to job specialization in Neolithic communities
Describe how social inequality might have emerged in agricultural societies
Create a diagram showing the relationship between agricultural surplus, population growth, and the development of specialized occupations

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and analyzing the key features that define a civilization, including cities, government, religion, writing, and art.

sub_topics.name: Eight Features of Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the defining characteristics that distinguish civilizations from simpler societies.
example_tasks: List and define the eight key features of civilization (cities, organized government, complex religion, job specialization, social classes, arts and architecture, public works, writing)
Explain why writing is considered essential for a society to be classified as a civilization
Evaluate whether a specific ancient society qualifies as a civilization by examining which features it possessed

sub_topics.name: Rise of Cities and Urban Centers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how and why the first cities emerged and their role in civilization development.
example_tasks: Describe three reasons why cities developed in river valleys during the Bronze Age
Compare a Neolithic village to an early city, identifying key differences in size, organization, and function
Analyze the layout of an ancient city and explain how its design reflects the civilization's priorities and values

name: Ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt
short_description: Students examine the rise of the world's first civilizations in the Fertile Crescent and Nile Valley, analyzing their governments, innovations, religious beliefs, and lasting contributions to human culture.

sub_topics.name: Mesopotamian Civilization and City-States
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring Sumer and other Mesopotamian societies between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.

sub_topics.name: Sumerian City-States and Government
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the political organization and governance of independent city-states like Ur and Uruk.
example_tasks: Explain what a city-state is and why Mesopotamia was organized this way rather than as one unified country
Describe the role of the lugal (king) in Sumerian city-states and how rulers claimed authority
Compare and contrast two Mesopotamian city-states in terms of size, power, and cultural achievements

sub_topics.name: Cuneiform Writing System
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about one of humanity's first writing systems and its importance for record-keeping and culture.
example_tasks: Explain how cuneiform developed from pictographs to a more abstract writing system
Describe three ways Mesopotamians used cuneiform writing in their daily lives and government
Analyze a cuneiform tablet and identify what type of document it is (business record, law, story) based on context clues

sub_topics.name: Mesopotamian Technological and Cultural Innovations
sub_topics.short_description: Examining key inventions including the wheel, irrigation, mathematics, and astronomy.
example_tasks: Identify five major Mesopotamian innovations and explain how each improved daily life or trade
Explain how Mesopotamian irrigation systems allowed agriculture to thrive in an arid climate
Describe the Mesopotamian contributions to mathematics, including their base-60 number system that influences our time-keeping today

sub_topics.name: Code of Hammurabi and Law
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing one of the earliest written law codes and its principles of justice.
example_tasks: Explain the principle of 'an eye for an eye' in Hammurabi's Code and what it reveals about Babylonian values
Analyze three specific laws from the Code of Hammurabi and determine whether they treated all people equally
Compare Hammurabi's Code to modern American laws, identifying similarities and differences in how crimes are punished

sub_topics.name: Ancient Egyptian Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Studying the unified kingdom along the Nile River, its pharaohs, religious beliefs, and monumental achievements.

sub_topics.name: Geography and the Nile River
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the Nile's predictable flooding enabled Egyptian civilization to flourish.
example_tasks: Explain Herodotus's statement that 'Egypt is the gift of the Nile' using specific geographic evidence
Describe how annual flooding of the Nile supported agriculture and why Egyptians could predict it
Compare the challenges of farming in Egypt versus Mesopotamia based on their different river systems

sub_topics.name: Pharaohs and Egyptian Government
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the divine kingship of pharaohs and the structure of Egyptian bureaucracy.
example_tasks: Explain why pharaohs were considered both political rulers and religious figures in ancient Egypt
Describe the social pyramid of ancient Egypt, including the roles of pharaohs, priests, scribes, and farmers
Analyze the accomplishments of a specific pharaoh (such as Hatshepsut, Ramses II, or Tutankhamun) and evaluate their impact on Egypt

sub_topics.name: Egyptian Religious Beliefs and Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about polytheistic religion, gods and goddesses, and beliefs about the afterlife.
example_tasks: Identify five major Egyptian gods (such as Ra, Osiris, Isis, Anubis, Horus) and explain their domains and importance
Describe the Egyptian mummification process and explain why preserving the body was important for their religious beliefs
Analyze passages from the Book of the Dead and explain what they reveal about Egyptian views of judgment and the afterlife

sub_topics.name: Pyramids and Monumental Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the construction and purpose of pyramids, temples, and other massive structures.
example_tasks: Explain the purpose of pyramids and why they were built as tombs for pharaohs
Describe the engineering challenges of building the Great Pyramid of Giza and theories about construction methods
Compare the Step Pyramid of Djoser to the Great Pyramid of Khufu, showing the evolution of pyramid design

sub_topics.name: Hieroglyphic Writing and the Rosetta Stone
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Egyptian writing system and how it was deciphered in modern times.
example_tasks: Describe the three types of symbols used in hieroglyphic writing (logograms, phonograms, determinatives)
Explain how the Rosetta Stone helped scholars decipher hieroglyphics and why it was so important
Write your name using hieroglyphic symbols and explain the process you used to translate it

sub_topics.name: Comparing Mesopotamian and Egyptian Civilizations
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing similarities and differences between these two foundational river valley civilizations.

sub_topics.name: Political Organization Differences
sub_topics.short_description: Contrasting the city-state system of Mesopotamia with Egypt's unified kingdom.
example_tasks: Compare the political organization of Mesopotamia (independent city-states) with Egypt (unified kingdom under pharaoh)
Explain how geographic factors influenced whether these civilizations remained divided or united
Evaluate which political system (city-states or unified kingdom) provided more stability and explain your reasoning

sub_topics.name: Cultural and Religious Comparisons
sub_topics.short_description: Examining different worldviews, religious practices, and cultural values between the civilizations.
example_tasks: Compare Mesopotamian and Egyptian views of the afterlife and explain how geography influenced these beliefs
Contrast the roles of priests and temples in Mesopotamia versus Egypt
Analyze art and architecture from both civilizations to identify differences in aesthetic values and cultural priorities

name: Ancient Greece
short_description: Students explore Greek city-states, the development of democracy in Athens, military society of Sparta, Persian and Peloponnesian Wars, Alexander the Great's conquests, and lasting Greek contributions to Western civilization in philosophy, arts, and science.

sub_topics.name: Geography and the Greek City-States
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Greece's mountainous terrain led to the development of independent polis (city-states).

sub_topics.name: Geographic Influences on Greek Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how mountains, islands, and seas shaped Greek political and economic development.
example_tasks: Explain how Greece's mountainous geography led to the development of independent city-states rather than one unified empire
Describe three ways the Mediterranean Sea influenced Greek civilization, including trade and colonization
Using a map, identify the locations of major Greek city-states and explain how their geographic positions affected their economies

sub_topics.name: The Polis and Greek Political Identity
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the city-state as the fundamental political unit of Greek civilization.
example_tasks: Define polis and explain its two main parts: the acropolis and agora
Describe how Greeks identified primarily with their city-state rather than as 'Greeks,' using examples from Athens and Sparta
Analyze why loyalty to one's polis was considered the highest civic virtue in ancient Greece

sub_topics.name: Athens and the Development of Democracy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the evolution of Athenian government from monarchy through democracy, and the principles of citizen participation.

sub_topics.name: Evolution of Athenian Democracy
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing the reforms of Solon, Cleisthenes, and Pericles that expanded democratic participation.
example_tasks: Describe the reforms of Solon and explain how they addressed economic inequality in Athens
Explain Cleisthenes' reorganization of Athens and why he is called the 'Father of Athenian Democracy'
Analyze Pericles' statement that Athens is 'the school of Greece' and evaluate whether Athenian democracy lived up to this ideal

sub_topics.name: Structure of Athenian Democratic Government
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Assembly, Council of 500, and courts, and how citizens participated directly.
example_tasks: Describe the role and powers of the Athenian Assembly (Ecclesia) and explain who could participate
Explain how the Council of 500 functioned and why Athenians used random selection (lottery) to choose members
Compare Athenian direct democracy to American representative democracy, identifying three key differences

sub_topics.name: Limitations and Exclusions in Athenian Democracy
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing who was excluded from citizenship and democratic participation in Athens.
example_tasks: Identify which groups were excluded from Athenian citizenship and political participation (women, slaves, foreigners)
Calculate what percentage of Athens' population actually had democratic rights and explain your reasoning
Evaluate whether ancient Athens should be considered a true democracy given its exclusion of most inhabitants

sub_topics.name: Athenian Golden Age and Cultural Achievements
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring Athens' cultural flourishing under Pericles, including art, architecture, and drama.
example_tasks: Describe three major achievements of Athens during its Golden Age under Pericles
Explain the significance of the Parthenon as both a religious temple and symbol of Athenian power
Analyze how Athenian drama (tragedies and comedies) reflected democratic values and civic concerns

sub_topics.name: Sparta and Military Society
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Sparta's unique social system focused on military excellence, discipline, and state service.

sub_topics.name: Spartan Government and Social Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Sparta's oligarchic government and rigid social hierarchy.
example_tasks: Describe Sparta's government structure, including the roles of two kings, the Council of Elders, and the Assembly
Explain Sparta's social classes: Spartiates (full citizens), Perioeci (free non-citizens), and Helots (state-owned serfs)
Analyze why Sparta maintained such a militaristic society, considering its need to control the helot population

sub_topics.name: Spartan Education and Military Training (Agoge)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the rigorous training system that shaped Spartan warriors from childhood.
example_tasks: Describe the agoge system and explain how Spartan boys were trained from age 7 to become soldiers
Compare the education of Spartan boys to Spartan girls, noting similarities and differences in physical training
Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of Sparta's educational system compared to Athens' focus on arts and philosophy

sub_topics.name: Comparing Athens and Sparta
sub_topics.short_description: Contrasting the values, governments, and ways of life in Greece's two most powerful city-states.
example_tasks: Create a comparison chart showing differences between Athens and Sparta in government, education, economy, and values
Explain which city-state valued individual freedom more and which valued discipline and collective good
Write a persuasive paragraph arguing whether you would prefer to live in Athens or Sparta, supporting your choice with specific evidence

sub_topics.name: The Persian Wars
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the conflict between Greek city-states and the Persian Empire, including key battles and Greek unity.

sub_topics.name: Causes of the Persian Wars
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Persia attempted to conquer Greece and how the conflict began.
example_tasks: Explain why the Ionian Revolt triggered Persian invasions of mainland Greece
Describe Darius I's and Xerxes' motivations for attempting to conquer Greece
Analyze how the Greek city-states' independence and Persian imperial expansion made conflict inevitable

sub_topics.name: Major Battles of the Persian Wars
sub_topics.short_description: Examining key military engagements including Marathon, Thermopylae, Salamis, and Plataea.
example_tasks: Describe the Battle of Marathon and explain how the outnumbered Athenians defeated the Persians
Explain the significance of the Spartan stand at Thermopylae, including why it became legendary despite being a defeat
Analyze how the Greek naval victory at Salamis proved decisive in the Persian Wars
Create a timeline of the Persian Wars showing the major battles and their outcomes from 490-479 BCE

sub_topics.name: Consequences of the Persian Wars
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating the impact of Greek victory on Athens' power and confidence.
example_tasks: Explain how Athens emerged as the dominant Greek power after the Persian Wars
Describe the formation of the Delian League and how it evolved into an Athenian empire
Analyze how Greek victory over Persia influenced Greek confidence and cultural achievements during the Golden Age

sub_topics.name: The Peloponnesian War
sub_topics.short_description: Studying the devastating conflict between Athens and Sparta that weakened the Greek city-states.

sub_topics.name: Causes and Outbreak of the Peloponnesian War
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the rivalry between Athens and Sparta that led to war.
example_tasks: Explain how Athens' growing power and control of the Delian League threatened Sparta
Describe Thucydides' analysis of the 'real cause' of the war: Spartan fear of Athenian expansion
Identify three specific incidents that escalated tensions and triggered the outbreak of war in 431 BCE

sub_topics.name: Major Events and Turning Points
sub_topics.short_description: Examining key phases of the war and strategic decisions by both sides.
example_tasks: Describe Pericles' strategy for Athens at the start of the war and why it ultimately failed
Explain how the plague in Athens affected the course of the war and Athenian morale
Analyze the disastrous Sicilian Expedition and its impact on Athens' ability to continue the war

sub_topics.name: Outcomes and Impact on Greece
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating how the war weakened all Greek city-states and ended Athens' golden age.
example_tasks: Describe the final defeat of Athens and the terms imposed by Sparta
Explain how the Peloponnesian War weakened all Greek city-states, not just the losers
Analyze whether the war had any 'winners' given the devastation it caused throughout Greece

sub_topics.name: Alexander the Great and Hellenistic Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Alexander's conquests, the spread of Greek culture, and the Hellenistic world that emerged.

sub_topics.name: Philip II of Macedon and Rise of Macedonia
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Macedonia unified Greece under its control.
example_tasks: Explain how Philip II took advantage of Greek weakness after the Peloponnesian War
Describe the military innovations Philip II introduced, including the Macedonian phalanx
Analyze why Greek city-states failed to unite against the Macedonian threat until it was too late

sub_topics.name: Alexander's Military Campaigns
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing Alexander's conquest of the Persian Empire and expansion into Asia.
example_tasks: Create a map showing the extent of Alexander's empire from Greece to India
Describe three major battles (Granicus, Issus, Gaugamela) that enabled Alexander to defeat Persia
Explain Alexander's military tactics and leadership qualities that made him so successful
Analyze why Alexander's troops finally refused to march further east into India

sub_topics.name: Hellenistic Culture and Legacy
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the blend of Greek and Eastern cultures that resulted from Alexander's conquests.
example_tasks: Define 'Hellenistic' and explain how it differs from 'Hellenic' (classical Greek culture)
Describe how Greek language and culture spread throughout Alexander's empire
Analyze the cultural exchange between Greek and Eastern civilizations in Hellenistic cities like Alexandria, Egypt
Explain how the division of Alexander's empire after his death affected the spread of Hellenistic culture

sub_topics.name: Greek Philosophy and Scientific Thought
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the contributions of Greek philosophers and scientists to Western intellectual tradition.

sub_topics.name: The Great Greek Philosophers
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle and their philosophical methods and ideas.
example_tasks: Describe the Socratic Method and explain how Socrates used questioning to help people examine their beliefs
Explain Plato's Theory of Forms and his vision of the ideal state in 'The Republic'
Describe Aristotle's contributions to logic, science, and ethics, and explain why his works influenced thinking for centuries
Compare the philosophical approaches of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle, showing how each built on the previous thinker

sub_topics.name: Greek Contributions to Science and Mathematics
sub_topics.short_description: Examining advances in mathematics, astronomy, medicine, and scientific thinking.
example_tasks: Describe Pythagoras' contributions to mathematics and explain the Pythagorean theorem
Explain Hippocrates' approach to medicine and why he is called the 'Father of Medicine'
Describe how Greek scientists like Aristarchus and Eratosthenes advanced understanding of astronomy and geography
Analyze how the Greek emphasis on reason and observation laid foundations for modern scientific method

sub_topics.name: Greek Art, Architecture, and Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Greek achievements in drama, epic poetry, architecture, and sculpture that influenced Western culture.

sub_topics.name: Greek Architecture and Sculpture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining architectural orders, temples, and idealized human form in sculpture.
example_tasks: Identify and describe the three classical Greek architectural orders: Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian
Explain the key features of Greek temples using the Parthenon as an example
Analyze how Greek sculptors portrayed the idealized human form and why this was significant
Describe how Greek architectural styles influenced later civilizations, including Rome and modern America

sub_topics.name: Greek Drama and Epic Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Greek theatrical traditions and epic poems like the Iliad and Odyssey.
example_tasks: Explain the characteristics of Greek tragedy and comedy, including the use of masks and choruses
Describe the themes explored in Homer's Iliad and Odyssey and their importance to Greek culture
Analyze a scene from a Greek tragedy (such as Sophocles' Antigone or Oedipus Rex) to identify the moral dilemma presented
Explain how Greek drama addressed civic issues and helped Athenian citizens think about justice and morality

name: Ancient Rome
short_description: Students analyze the rise of Rome from republic to empire, Roman government and law, military expansion, cultural achievements, the spread of Christianity, and the eventual decline and fall of the Western Roman Empire.

sub_topics.name: The Roman Republic
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the establishment and structure of the Roman Republic, including its government, social classes, and expansion.

sub_topics.name: Founding of Rome and Early Legends
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Rome's legendary founding and transition from monarchy to republic.
example_tasks: Retell the legend of Romulus and Remus and explain what it reveals about Roman values
Explain why Romans overthrew their last king and established a republic in 509 BCE
Describe the geographic advantages of Rome's location on the Tiber River and seven hills

sub_topics.name: Structure of Republican Government
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the checks and balances in Roman government, including consuls, Senate, and assemblies.
example_tasks: Describe the powers and limitations of Roman consuls and explain why there were two rather than one
Explain the role of the Roman Senate and which social class dominated it
Analyze how the Roman Republic's system of checks and balances prevented any one person from gaining too much power
Compare the Roman Republic's government structure to the United States government, identifying similarities and differences

sub_topics.name: Patricians and Plebeians: Social Conflict
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding class struggles and the gradual expansion of plebeian political rights.
example_tasks: Compare the rights and privileges of patricians versus plebeians in early Republican Rome
Describe the Conflict of the Orders and explain how plebeians gained political power over time
Explain the importance of the Twelve Tables as Rome's first written law code and why plebeians demanded it
Analyze the role of tribunes in protecting plebeian interests and their power of veto

sub_topics.name: Roman Military Expansion During the Republic
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing Rome's conquest of Italy and the Mediterranean world.
example_tasks: Describe how Rome gradually conquered the Italian peninsula through military force and alliances
Explain the causes and outcomes of the Punic Wars between Rome and Carthage
Analyze Hannibal's invasion of Italy during the Second Punic War and why he ultimately failed
Create a map showing the expansion of Roman territory from 500 BCE to 100 BCE

sub_topics.name: Crisis of the Republic and Rise of Julius Caesar
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the social, economic, and political problems that destabilized the Republic and led to dictatorship.

sub_topics.name: Problems of the Late Republic
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding economic inequality, military reforms, and political corruption that weakened republican government.
example_tasks: Describe the economic problems caused by Rome's expansion, including the growth of latifundia (large estates) and displacement of small farmers
Explain the reforms of the Gracchus brothers and why they were assassinated by Senate conservatives
Analyze how Marius' military reforms changed the Roman army and soldiers' loyalty from the Republic to individual generals

sub_topics.name: Julius Caesar and the End of the Republic
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing Caesar's rise to power, dictatorship, and assassination.
example_tasks: Describe the First Triumvirate and how Caesar, Pompey, and Crassus cooperated to gain power
Explain Caesar's conquest of Gaul and how it increased his popularity and military strength
Analyze the significance of Caesar crossing the Rubicon River and saying 'the die is cast'
Describe the reasons conspirators gave for assassinating Caesar on the Ides of March (March 15, 44 BCE)
Evaluate whether Caesar's assassination saved the Republic or ensured its destruction

sub_topics.name: The Roman Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Studying the establishment of imperial rule under Augustus, Pax Romana, and the expansion and administration of the empire.

sub_topics.name: Augustus and the Foundation of the Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Octavian became Augustus and transformed Rome into an empire while maintaining republican appearances.
example_tasks: Explain how Octavian defeated Mark Antony and Cleopatra to become sole ruler of Rome
Describe how Augustus maintained the appearance of republican government while holding real power
Analyze the title 'Augustus' and other honors bestowed on Octavian and what they signified
Evaluate Augustus' claim that he 'restored the Republic' - was this accurate or propaganda?

sub_topics.name: Pax Romana and Imperial Administration
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the period of relative peace and prosperity during the first two centuries of empire.
example_tasks: Define Pax Romana and explain what made this two-century period relatively peaceful and stable
Describe how Roman emperors governed such a vast empire, including the role of provincial governors and the military
Explain the importance of Roman roads, aqueducts, and other infrastructure in maintaining the empire
Analyze the benefits and costs of Pax Romana for conquered peoples living under Roman rule

sub_topics.name: Notable Roman Emperors
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about significant emperors and their contributions or failures.
example_tasks: Compare the rules of the 'Five Good Emperors' (Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius) to earlier or later emperors
Describe the reign of Nero and why he is remembered as one of Rome's worst emperors
Explain Hadrian's Wall and what it reveals about Roman defensive strategy in Britain
Analyze the challenges Marcus Aurelius faced, including wars and plague, despite being a philosopher-emperor

sub_topics.name: Roman Culture and Achievements
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring Roman contributions to law, engineering, architecture, literature, and language that influenced Western civilization.

sub_topics.name: Roman Law and Legal Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the development of Roman law and its lasting influence on modern legal systems.
example_tasks: Explain the concept of 'innocent until proven guilty' and other Roman legal principles still used today
Describe the difference between civil law (for citizens) and the law of nations (for all people)
Analyze how the Twelve Tables, Republic law, and later imperial law evolved over time
Identify three principles from Roman law that influenced the American legal system

sub_topics.name: Roman Engineering and Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Roman innovations in construction, including arches, domes, concrete, and monumental buildings.
example_tasks: Explain how Romans used arches, vaults, and concrete to build massive structures like the Colosseum and Pantheon
Describe the Roman aqueduct system and why it was an engineering marvel
Analyze the architectural features of the Pantheon's dome and explain why it remains impressive today
Compare Roman architecture (focusing on engineering and practicality) to Greek architecture (focusing on beauty and proportion)

sub_topics.name: Roman Literature and Latin Language
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Roman writers, poets, and the spread of Latin throughout the empire.
example_tasks: Identify major Roman writers (Virgil, Ovid, Cicero, Caesar) and describe their most famous works
Explain how Virgil's Aeneid served as Roman national epic and promoted Augustus' rule
Describe how Latin became the common language of the western Roman Empire
Analyze how Latin evolved into modern Romance languages (Italian, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Romanian)

sub_topics.name: Daily Life in Ancient Rome
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding social structure, family life, entertainment, and living conditions in Roman society.
example_tasks: Describe the structure of a typical Roman family, including the authority of the paterfamilias
Explain the different types of entertainment Romans enjoyed, including gladiatorial games, chariot races, and theater
Compare the living conditions of wealthy Romans (living in domus or villas) versus poor Romans (living in insulae)
Analyze the role of slavery in Roman society and the economy

sub_topics.name: Rise of Christianity in the Roman Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the origins of Christianity, its spread through the empire, periods of persecution, and eventual acceptance.

sub_topics.name: Origins of Christianity and Jesus of Nazareth
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the life and teachings of Jesus in the context of Roman-controlled Judea.
example_tasks: Describe the political and religious situation in Judea during Jesus' lifetime
Explain the central teachings of Jesus as recorded in the Gospels
Analyze why Jesus was crucified by Roman authorities around 30 CE
Describe how Jesus' followers came to believe in his resurrection and began spreading his message

sub_topics.name: Spread of Christianity Through the Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how Christianity expanded from a small Jewish sect to a major religion across the Roman world.
example_tasks: Describe Paul's role in spreading Christianity to gentiles (non-Jews) throughout the Roman Empire
Explain why Christianity appealed to many people in the Roman Empire, including slaves and women
Analyze how Roman roads, common language (Latin and Greek), and Pax Romana facilitated the spread of Christianity
Create a map showing the spread of Christianity from Jerusalem throughout the Mediterranean world by 300 CE

sub_topics.name: Christian Persecution and Constantine's Conversion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Christians were persecuted and how Christianity became the empire's official religion.
example_tasks: Explain why Roman authorities persecuted Christians, including their refusal to worship Roman gods and the emperor
Describe the persecution under emperors like Nero and Diocletian
Explain Constantine's conversion to Christianity and the Edict of Milan (313 CE) that granted religious tolerance
Analyze how Christianity changed after Theodosius made it the official Roman religion in 380 CE

sub_topics.name: Decline and Fall of the Western Roman Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the multiple factors that contributed to the weakening and eventual collapse of the Western Roman Empire in 476 CE.

sub_topics.name: Internal Problems Weakening the Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Examining political instability, economic troubles, and social decay within the empire.
example_tasks: Describe the political instability of the third century, when numerous emperors were assassinated by their own armies
Explain the economic problems facing the late empire, including inflation, high taxes, and disrupted trade
Analyze how the division of the empire into Eastern and Western halves affected its ability to defend itself
Describe the decline of civic virtue and military discipline compared to earlier Roman periods

sub_topics.name: Germanic Invasions and Barbarian Migrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Germanic tribes and other groups crossed Roman borders and eventually established kingdoms.
example_tasks: Explain why Germanic tribes began migrating into Roman territory, including pressure from the Huns
Describe major invasions, including the Visigoths' sack of Rome in 410 CE and the Vandals' sack in 455 CE
Analyze the Battle of Adrianople (378 CE) and its significance in showing Rome's military weakness
Explain how Odoacer's deposition of the last Western Roman emperor Romulus Augustulus in 476 CE marked the traditional end of the Western Empire

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Multiple Causes of Rome's Fall
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing and weighing various factors historians identify as contributing to Rome's decline.
example_tasks: Create a chart listing internal and external factors that contributed to Rome's fall and evaluate which were most significant
Explain why the Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Empire survived while the Western Empire fell
Analyze different historical interpretations of Rome's fall (military defeat, economic collapse, moral decay, disease)
Write an argument defending which factor you believe was most important in causing Rome's fall, supporting your claim with evidence

sub_topics.name: Roman Legacy and Influence on Western Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Roman achievements continued to influence Europe and the world after the empire's fall.
example_tasks: Identify five lasting Roman contributions to Western civilization (law, language, architecture, engineering, government)
Explain how the Roman Catholic Church preserved Roman culture and learning during the Middle Ages
Describe examples of Roman influence in American government, architecture, and language
Analyze the concept of the 'fall' of Rome - did Roman civilization truly end in 476 CE or continue in modified forms?

name: Ancient Asian Civilizations
short_description: Students explore the development of major civilizations in China and India, examining their philosophies, religions, political systems, cultural achievements, and lasting influences on Asian and world history.

sub_topics.name: Ancient China and Dynastic Cycles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Chinese dynasties, philosophical traditions, and innovations from the Shang through the Han dynasty.

sub_topics.name: Early Chinese Dynasties: Shang and Zhou
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the first documented Chinese dynasties and the concept of the Mandate of Heaven.
example_tasks: Describe the Shang Dynasty's achievements, including bronze casting and oracle bones for divination
Explain the concept of the Mandate of Heaven and how it justified dynastic change in China
Analyze how the Zhou Dynasty's feudal system organized Chinese society
Compare the Mandate of Heaven to the divine right of kings in European monarchies

sub_topics.name: Chinese Philosophy: Confucianism and Daoism
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the teachings of Confucius and Laozi and their influence on Chinese culture and government.
example_tasks: Explain Confucius' teachings about proper relationships, filial piety, and social harmony
Describe the Daoist philosophy of living in harmony with nature and the concept of the Dao (the Way)
Compare Confucian emphasis on social order and duty to Daoist emphasis on spontaneity and simplicity
Analyze how Confucianism became the basis for Chinese government and education for over 2,000 years
Explain the concept of yin and yang and its importance in Chinese thought

sub_topics.name: Qin Dynasty and Unification of China
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the Qin Dynasty unified China through legalism and standardization.
example_tasks: Describe how Qin Shi Huangdi unified China by conquering rival states during the Warring States period
Explain the legalist philosophy adopted by the Qin Dynasty and how it differed from Confucianism
Analyze the standardization policies of the Qin (unified writing, currency, weights and measures, roads)
Describe the construction of the Great Wall of China and the human cost involved
Explain why the Qin Dynasty was so short-lived despite its achievements in unification

sub_topics.name: Han Dynasty and Chinese Golden Age
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the long-lasting Han Dynasty and its cultural and technological achievements.
example_tasks: Describe how the Han Dynasty established a stable government that lasted over 400 years
Explain the civil service examination system and how it selected government officials based on Confucian learning
Identify major Han Dynasty inventions and innovations (paper, the seismograph, improved iron tools, the wheelbarrow)
Describe the Silk Road and its importance in connecting China to Central Asia, India, and Rome
Analyze why the Han Dynasty is considered a golden age of Chinese civilization

sub_topics.name: Ancient Chinese Cultural and Technological Achievements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Chinese contributions to art, science, technology, and philosophy.
example_tasks: Describe Chinese achievements in art, including silk weaving, jade carving, and landscape painting
Explain Chinese innovations in technology that influenced the world (paper, gunpowder, compass, printing)
Analyze Chinese traditional medicine and its different approach from Western medicine
Compare Chinese writing system (logographic characters) to alphabetic writing systems

sub_topics.name: Ancient Indian Civilizations and Religions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the Indus Valley civilization, the development of Hinduism and Buddhism, and the major Indian empires.

sub_topics.name: Indus Valley Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about one of the world's earliest urban civilizations and its sophisticated planning.
example_tasks: Describe the major cities of the Indus Valley civilization, including Mohenjo-Daro and Harappa
Explain the evidence of urban planning found in Indus Valley cities (grid patterns, sewage systems, standardized bricks)
Analyze why the Indus Valley civilization declined and eventually disappeared around 1900 BCE
Compare the Indus Valley civilization to Mesopotamia and Egypt in terms of urban development

sub_topics.name: Development of Hinduism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the beliefs, practices, and social structure of Hinduism.
example_tasks: Explain the core Hindu beliefs in Brahman (universal spirit), dharma (duty), karma (actions and consequences), and reincarnation
Describe the Hindu caste system (varnas) and how it organized Indian society
Identify major Hindu deities (Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva) and their roles
Analyze how the concept of karma and dharma influenced behavior in Hindu society
Explain the goals of Hindu life: dharma, artha (wealth), kama (pleasure), and moksha (liberation)

sub_topics.name: Buddhism: Life and Teachings of the Buddha
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Siddhartha Gautama and the fundamental teachings of Buddhism.
example_tasks: Describe Siddhartha Gautama's life story and his journey from prince to enlightened Buddha
Explain the Four Noble Truths that form the foundation of Buddhist teaching
Describe the Eightfold Path as the Buddhist way to end suffering and achieve enlightenment
Compare Buddhist rejection of the caste system to Hinduism's acceptance of it
Analyze how Buddhism spread beyond India to other parts of Asia

sub_topics.name: Mauryan Empire and Ashoka
sub_topics.short_description: Examining India's first major empire and Emperor Ashoka's conversion to Buddhism.
example_tasks: Describe how Chandragupta Maurya unified much of India into the first major Indian empire
Explain Emperor Ashoka's conversion to Buddhism after witnessing the horrors of war
Analyze Ashoka's edicts and policies that promoted Buddhist values like nonviolence and religious tolerance
Evaluate Ashoka's reign as an example of how religious beliefs can influence political leadership

sub_topics.name: Gupta Empire: India's Golden Age
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the cultural and scientific achievements during India's classical period.
example_tasks: Describe why the Gupta period is called India's golden age of culture and learning
Identify major achievements in mathematics during the Gupta period (concept of zero, decimal system, pi calculation)
Explain Gupta advances in astronomy, medicine, and metallurgy
Describe the flowering of Sanskrit literature and Hindu art during the Gupta era
Analyze how Gupta mathematical innovations influenced the development of mathematics worldwide

sub_topics.name: The Silk Road and Cultural Exchange
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the trade networks connecting Asia, the Middle East, and Europe, and the exchange of goods, ideas, and religions.

sub_topics.name: Silk Road Trade Routes and Commerce
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the network of trade routes and the goods exchanged between civilizations.
example_tasks: Describe the main routes of the Silk Road connecting China to the Mediterranean world
Identify major goods traded along the Silk Road from China (silk, porcelain, tea, paper) and goods coming to China (gold, silver, precious stones, horses)
Explain the role of Central Asian intermediaries in Silk Road trade
Analyze how the Silk Road connected the major civilizations of the ancient world

sub_topics.name: Cultural and Religious Exchange
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how ideas, religions, and technologies spread along trade routes.
example_tasks: Describe how Buddhism spread from India to Central Asia, China, Korea, and Japan along the Silk Road
Explain the diffusion of technologies like papermaking and gunpowder from China westward
Analyze how the Silk Road facilitated cultural exchange between East and West
Evaluate the statement that 'ideas traveled farther than goods' along the Silk Road

name: Medieval Europe and Feudalism
short_description: Students examine the political, economic, and social structure of medieval European society, including the feudal system, the role of the Catholic Church, the Crusades, and the impact of the Black Death on European civilization.

sub_topics.name: Fall of Rome and the Early Middle Ages
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the transition from Roman civilization to medieval Europe and the role of Germanic kingdoms.

sub_topics.name: Germanic Kingdoms and Charlemagne
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the Franks and Charlemagne's attempt to revive the Roman Empire.
example_tasks: Describe how Germanic tribes established kingdoms in former Roman territories after 476 CE
Explain Charlemagne's achievements in uniting much of Western Europe and his coronation as Roman Emperor in 800 CE
Analyze the Treaty of Verdun (843 CE) and how it divided Charlemagne's empire among his grandsons
Evaluate Charlemagne's efforts to promote education and preserve classical learning during the Carolingian Renaissance

sub_topics.name: Viking, Magyar, and Muslim Invasions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the threats and instability that led to the development of feudalism.
example_tasks: Describe the Viking raids on European coastal areas and monasteries from the 800s to 1000s
Explain how Magyar invasions from the east threatened central Europe
Analyze how Muslim control of the Mediterranean disrupted trade and contributed to European isolation
Evaluate how these invasions weakened centralized authority and led people to seek local protection

sub_topics.name: The Feudal System
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the political, economic, and social structure that organized medieval society through reciprocal obligations.

sub_topics.name: Feudal Hierarchy and Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the lord-vassal relationship and the exchange of land for military service.
example_tasks: Describe the feudal hierarchy from king to nobles to knights to peasants
Explain the mutual obligations between lords and vassals in the feudal contract
Define important feudal terms: fief (land grant), homage (ceremony of loyalty), fealty (oath of faithfulness)
Analyze why feudalism developed as a response to the lack of strong central government
Create a diagram showing the feudal pyramid and the exchange of land for loyalty and military service

sub_topics.name: Manorialism and the Medieval Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the self-sufficient manor as the basic economic unit of medieval society.
example_tasks: Describe the layout and organization of a typical medieval manor
Explain the difference between feudalism (political/military system) and manorialism (economic system)
Compare the lives and obligations of serfs versus free peasants on the manor
Analyze why the manorial system was largely self-sufficient with little trade beyond the manor

sub_topics.name: Knights and the Code of Chivalry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the role of knights in medieval society and their code of conduct.
example_tasks: Describe the training process for becoming a knight (page, squire, knight)
Explain the ideals of chivalry and how knights were expected to behave toward nobles, the Church, and ladies
Analyze the contrast between chivalric ideals and the actual violent behavior of many knights
Describe medieval tournaments and their role in training knights and displaying martial skills

sub_topics.name: The Catholic Church in Medieval Life
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the dominant role of the Church in medieval European religion, politics, education, and daily life.

sub_topics.name: Church Authority and Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the hierarchical structure of the Church and the power of the Pope.
example_tasks: Describe the hierarchy of the Catholic Church from Pope to cardinals, bishops, and parish priests
Explain how the Church influenced political affairs and sometimes clashed with kings over authority
Analyze the conflict between Pope Gregory VII and Holy Roman Emperor Henry IV over lay investiture
Describe the significance of excommunication and interdict as weapons the Church used against rulers

sub_topics.name: Monasticism and Religious Life
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about monks, nuns, and their role in preserving knowledge and providing services.
example_tasks: Describe the daily life of monks and nuns following the Rule of Saint Benedict
Explain how monasteries preserved classical learning by copying manuscripts
Analyze the various services monasteries provided to medieval society (schools, hospitals, food for travelers)
Compare the contemplative life of monks to the active life of friars like the Franciscans and Dominicans

sub_topics.name: The Church in Daily Medieval Life
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how religion shaped every aspect of medieval people's lives.
example_tasks: Describe the seven sacraments and their importance in a medieval Christian's life from birth to death
Explain why the parish church was the center of village life in medieval Europe
Analyze how Christian beliefs about sin, salvation, and the afterlife influenced medieval behavior
Describe the role of saints, relics, and pilgrimages in medieval religious practice

sub_topics.name: The Crusades
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the religious wars between Christians and Muslims for control of the Holy Land and their impact on Europe and the Middle East.

sub_topics.name: Causes and the First Crusade
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Europeans launched military expeditions to reclaim Jerusalem.
example_tasks: Explain Pope Urban II's call for crusade in 1095 and the religious motivations he emphasized
Describe additional motivations for joining the crusades (desire for land, wealth, adventure, forgiveness of sins)
Analyze the success of the First Crusade in capturing Jerusalem in 1099
Describe the establishment of Crusader States in the Middle East

sub_topics.name: Later Crusades and Outcomes
sub_topics.short_description: Examining subsequent crusades and the eventual Muslim reconquest of the Holy Land.
example_tasks: Describe the Third Crusade and the conflict between Richard the Lionheart and Saladin
Explain how the Fourth Crusade was diverted to attack Constantinople instead of Muslim territories
Analyze why the crusades ultimately failed to maintain Christian control of the Holy Land
Evaluate the Children's Crusade and what it reveals about crusading fervor

sub_topics.name: Impact and Legacy of the Crusades
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the long-term effects of the crusades on Europe, the Middle East, and Christian-Muslim relations.
example_tasks: Describe how the crusades increased European contact with Byzantine and Islamic civilizations
Explain how the crusades stimulated trade between Europe and the East
Analyze the negative impacts of the crusades, including massacres, destruction, and lasting religious animosity
Evaluate how the crusades strengthened the power of kings at the expense of feudal nobles
Discuss how the crusades are remembered differently in Western and Islamic historical traditions

sub_topics.name: Medieval Culture and Learning
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring intellectual life, education, architecture, and cultural achievements of the Middle Ages.

sub_topics.name: Rise of Universities and Scholasticism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the development of higher education and philosophical thought.
example_tasks: Describe the establishment of medieval universities like Bologna, Paris, and Oxford
Explain what students studied in medieval universities (trivium and quadrivium, theology, law, medicine)
Define scholasticism and its attempt to reconcile faith and reason
Analyze Thomas Aquinas's contributions to medieval philosophy and theology

sub_topics.name: Gothic Architecture and Cathedrals
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the architectural innovations and symbolism of Gothic cathedrals.
example_tasks: Identify key features of Gothic architecture: pointed arches, ribbed vaults, flying buttresses, stained glass
Explain how Gothic architectural innovations allowed cathedrals to be built taller with large windows
Analyze the religious symbolism and purpose of Gothic cathedrals as representations of heaven
Describe famous Gothic cathedrals like Notre Dame de Paris or Chartres Cathedral

sub_topics.name: Medieval Literature and Epic Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Examining literary works that reflect medieval values and society.
example_tasks: Describe the characteristics of medieval epic poems and romances
Analyze themes in works like Beowulf, The Song of Roland, or Arthurian legends
Explain how Geoffrey Chaucer's Canterbury Tales provides insight into medieval society
Compare vernacular literature (written in local languages) to Latin literature in the Middle Ages

sub_topics.name: Late Middle Ages: Crisis and Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the disasters and transformations that marked the decline of medieval civilization.

sub_topics.name: The Black Death and Its Impact
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the devastating plague pandemic of the 14th century and its social consequences.
example_tasks: Describe how the bubonic plague spread from Asia to Europe along trade routes in 1347-1351
Explain the symptoms of the plague and medieval understanding of its causes
Analyze the demographic impact: approximately one-third of Europe's population died
Describe how the Black Death led to labor shortages and weakened the feudal system
Explain social and psychological effects of the plague, including persecution of Jews and increased religious fanaticism

sub_topics.name: The Hundred Years' War
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the long conflict between England and France and the rise of national identity.
example_tasks: Explain the causes of the Hundred Years' War, including disputes over French succession and English territories
Describe key battles like Crécy, Poitiers, and Agincourt where English longbowmen defeated French knights
Analyze the role of Joan of Arc in inspiring French resistance and turning the tide of the war
Evaluate how the war contributed to the decline of feudalism and the rise of national monarchies

sub_topics.name: Decline of Church Authority
sub_topics.short_description: Examining challenges to papal power including the Babylonian Captivity and Great Schism.
example_tasks: Describe the Babylonian Captivity (1309-1377) when popes resided in Avignon under French influence
Explain the Great Schism (1378-1417) when rival popes claimed authority simultaneously
Analyze how these events weakened the Church's moral authority and spiritual prestige
Describe early critics of the Church like John Wycliffe and Jan Hus who challenged Church practices

name: Islamic Civilization and the Middle East
short_description: Students explore the origins and spread of Islam, the accomplishments of Islamic civilization during its Golden Age, and Muslim contributions to science, mathematics, medicine, philosophy, and the arts.

sub_topics.name: Origins and Beliefs of Islam
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the life of Muhammad, the basic teachings of Islam, and the Quran.

sub_topics.name: Life of Muhammad and Founding of Islam
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Muhammad's life in Mecca and Medina and his role as God's messenger.
example_tasks: Describe Muhammad's early life in Mecca and his experience receiving revelations from Allah through the angel Gabriel
Explain the significance of the Hijra (migration) from Mecca to Medina in 622 CE as the beginning of the Islamic calendar
Analyze why Muhammad faced opposition from Meccan leaders and how he eventually returned to conquer Mecca
Describe Muhammad's role as both religious leader and political/military leader in establishing the Islamic community

sub_topics.name: The Five Pillars of Islam
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the fundamental practices and obligations of Muslim faith.
example_tasks: List and explain the Five Pillars of Islam: shahada (declaration of faith), salat (prayer), zakat (charity), sawm (fasting), hajj (pilgrimage)
Describe how Muslims practice daily prayers (salat) and the significance of praying toward Mecca
Explain the importance of the hajj pilgrimage to Mecca and what pilgrims do during the journey
Analyze how the Five Pillars create unity among Muslims worldwide regardless of cultural differences

sub_topics.name: The Quran and Core Islamic Beliefs
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Islam's holy book and fundamental theological concepts.
example_tasks: Explain Muslims' belief that the Quran is the literal word of God revealed to Muhammad
Describe core Islamic beliefs: monotheism (one God/Allah), prophethood, judgment day, angels
Compare Islamic beliefs about prophets, including Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad as the final prophet
Explain the concept of submission to Allah's will and what 'Islam' means

sub_topics.name: Expansion of Islamic Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the rapid spread of Islam across the Middle East, North Africa, and beyond through conquest and conversion.

sub_topics.name: The Early Caliphates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the leadership succession after Muhammad and territorial expansion.
example_tasks: Explain what a caliph is and the role of the first four 'rightly guided caliphs' after Muhammad's death
Describe how Muslim armies conquered Byzantine and Persian territories in the decades after Muhammad's death
Create a map showing the extent of Islamic expansion under the Umayyad Caliphate (661-750 CE)
Analyze reasons for the rapid success of Islamic expansion (military skill, weakness of enemies, appeal of Islamic message)

sub_topics.name: Sunni-Shia Division
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the origins of the major split within Islam over leadership succession.
example_tasks: Explain the origins of the Sunni-Shia split following the death of Muhammad
Describe the Sunni position that caliphs should be chosen by the community
Describe the Shia position that leadership should remain in Muhammad's family through his cousin Ali
Analyze how this initial political dispute evolved into broader theological and practice differences
Identify regions where Sunni and Shia Muslims are predominant today

sub_topics.name: The Abbasid Caliphate and Baghdad
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the dynasty that ushered in Islam's Golden Age.
example_tasks: Describe how the Abbasids overthrew the Umayyads and moved the capital to Baghdad
Explain why Baghdad became a major center of learning, culture, and trade
Analyze how the Abbasid caliphs encouraged scholarship and translation of classical texts
Describe the court of Harun al-Rashid as representative of Abbasid cultural sophistication

sub_topics.name: Islamic Golden Age: Cultural and Scientific Achievements
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring Muslim contributions to mathematics, science, medicine, philosophy, and the arts during the medieval period.

sub_topics.name: Mathematics and Scientific Advances
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Muslim achievements in algebra, astronomy, chemistry, and other sciences.
example_tasks: Describe al-Khwarizmi's contributions to mathematics, including algebra (the word comes from his work)
Explain Islamic advances in astronomy, including improved astronomical tables and instruments like the astrolabe
Analyze how Muslim scholars built upon Greek, Indian, and Persian knowledge
Identify other important Muslim scientists like Ibn al-Haytham (optics) and al-Razi (chemistry and medicine)

sub_topics.name: Islamic Medicine and Hospitals
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about medical knowledge and practice in the Islamic world.
example_tasks: Describe the contributions of physicians like Ibn Sina (Avicenna) whose medical encyclopedia was used in Europe for centuries
Explain how Islamic hospitals were organized and provided free care to patients
Analyze how Muslim doctors advanced knowledge of diseases, surgery, and pharmacology
Compare Islamic medical knowledge to European medical practice during the same period

sub_topics.name: Preservation and Translation of Classical Knowledge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Muslim scholars preserved Greek philosophy and science.
example_tasks: Describe the House of Wisdom in Baghdad and its role as a center for translating Greek texts into Arabic
Explain how Muslim scholars preserved works of Aristotle, Plato, and other Greek philosophers
Analyze how this preserved knowledge later returned to Europe through Muslim Spain
Evaluate the role of Muslim scholars like Averroes (Ibn Rushd) in commenting on and interpreting Aristotle

sub_topics.name: Islamic Art and Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining distinctive features of Islamic artistic traditions.
example_tasks: Describe key features of Islamic architecture: domes, minarets, arches, courtyards
Explain the use of geometric patterns, arabesques, and calligraphy in Islamic art
Analyze why Islamic art typically avoids depicting human or animal figures in religious contexts
Describe famous examples of Islamic architecture like the Dome of the Rock, Alhambra, or Taj Mahal

sub_topics.name: Islamic Literature and Philosophy
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about literary works and philosophical thought in the Islamic world.
example_tasks: Describe the importance of poetry in Islamic culture and examples like The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam
Explain how Muslim philosophers tried to reconcile Islamic faith with Greek reason
Analyze the global influence of stories from The Thousand and One Nights (Arabian Nights)
Compare Islamic philosophy's treatment of reason and faith to European scholasticism

sub_topics.name: Islamic Trade Networks and Urban Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Muslim merchants connected Africa, Europe, and Asia, and the cosmopolitan nature of Islamic cities.

sub_topics.name: Islamic Trade Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how Muslim merchants dominated trade routes connecting three continents.
example_tasks: Describe the trade routes controlled by Muslim merchants across the Mediterranean, Indian Ocean, and Silk Road
Identify goods traded through Islamic networks (spices, textiles, precious metals, slaves, ideas)
Explain how Islamic trade networks spread Islam to new regions like Southeast Asia and West Africa
Analyze the role of Muslim merchants in cultural exchange between different civilizations

sub_topics.name: Great Islamic Cities and Urban Life
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about major urban centers and cosmopolitan culture of the Islamic world.
example_tasks: Describe the features of major Islamic cities like Baghdad, Cairo, Cordoba, and Damascus
Explain the importance of the mosque as the center of Islamic city life
Analyze the role of bazaars (markets/souks) in Islamic urban economies and social life
Compare the size, sophistication, and diversity of medieval Islamic cities to European cities of the same period

sub_topics.name: Islamic Spain (Al-Andalus)
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Muslim rule in Iberia and the unique multicultural society that developed there.

sub_topics.name: Muslim Conquest and Rule of Spain
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Muslims controlled most of the Iberian Peninsula for centuries.
example_tasks: Describe the Muslim conquest of Spain in 711 CE and the defeat of the Visigothic kingdom
Explain why Muslim Spain (Al-Andalus) became one of the most advanced regions in medieval Europe
Analyze the multicultural society of Al-Andalus where Muslims, Christians, and Jews coexisted
Describe the Umayyad Caliphate of Cordoba and its cultural achievements

sub_topics.name: Cordoba as a Center of Learning
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the intellectual and cultural achievements of Muslim Spain.
example_tasks: Describe Cordoba in the 10th century as one of the largest and most cultured cities in the world
Explain the Great Mosque of Cordoba and its architectural significance
Analyze how Muslim Spain served as a bridge for transmitting Islamic learning to Christian Europe
Describe the translation schools where Arabic texts were translated into Latin

sub_topics.name: The Reconquista and End of Muslim Spain
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the gradual Christian reconquest of the Iberian Peninsula.
example_tasks: Define the Reconquista as the centuries-long Christian effort to reclaim Iberia from Muslim rule
Describe major stages of the Reconquista from the 8th to 15th centuries
Explain the fall of Granada in 1492 as the end of Muslim political power in Spain
Analyze the fate of Muslims and Jews in Spain after the Christian reconquest

name: African Kingdoms and Civilizations
short_description: Students explore the rich history of African civilizations south of the Sahara, including the great trading empires of West Africa, East African city-states, and diverse African cultures, achievements, and contributions.

sub_topics.name: West African Trading Empires
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the powerful kingdoms that grew wealthy from trans-Saharan trade in gold and salt.

sub_topics.name: Empire of Ghana
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the earliest of the great West African trading empires.
example_tasks: Describe Ghana's location between gold mines to the south and salt deposits to the north
Explain how Ghana grew wealthy by taxing trade goods passing through its territory
Analyze the system of silent bartering used in the gold trade to maintain secrecy about gold sources
Describe the downfall of Ghana due to invasion by the Almoravids and loss of trade control

sub_topics.name: Empire of Mali
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the most famous West African empire and its greatest ruler, Mansa Musa.
example_tasks: Describe how Sundiata Keita founded the Mali Empire in the 13th century
Explain Mansa Musa's famous pilgrimage to Mecca in 1324 and its impact on Mali's reputation
Analyze how Mansa Musa's generous gift-giving during his hajj revealed Mali's enormous wealth
Describe Timbuktu as a major center of Islamic learning and trade under Mali's rule
Evaluate the role of griots (oral historians) in preserving West African history and culture

sub_topics.name: Songhai Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the largest of the West African empires and its sophisticated administration.
example_tasks: Describe how Songhai emerged as the dominant power after Mali's decline
Explain the accomplishments of leaders like Sunni Ali and Askia Muhammad
Analyze the efficient government bureaucracy and legal system established by Askia Muhammad
Describe the great cities of Songhai including Gao and Timbuktu
Explain how the Moroccan invasion of 1591 led to Songhai's collapse

sub_topics.name: Trans-Saharan Trade Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the trade routes connecting West Africa to North Africa and the Mediterranean.
example_tasks: Describe the trans-Saharan trade routes and the role of camel caravans in crossing the desert
Explain the saying 'salt for gold, gold for salt' and why both commodities were valuable
Analyze how Islam spread to West Africa through trade contacts with North African Muslims
Identify other goods traded across the Sahara besides gold and salt (slaves, ivory, kola nuts, cloth)

sub_topics.name: East African City-States and Indian Ocean Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the Swahili coast trading cities and their connections to the broader Indian Ocean world.

sub_topics.name: Swahili City-States
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the cosmopolitan trading cities along Africa's east coast.
example_tasks: Describe major Swahili city-states like Kilwa, Mombasa, and Zanzibar
Explain how Swahili culture blended African and Arab influences
Analyze the development of the Swahili language as a blend of Bantu and Arabic
Describe the architectural features of Swahili cities including coral stone buildings and mosques

sub_topics.name: Indian Ocean Trade Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how East African cities connected to trade routes spanning from Africa to China.
example_tasks: Identify goods exported from East Africa (gold, ivory, enslaved people) and imports (cloth, porcelain, spices)
Explain the role of monsoon winds in facilitating seasonal trade across the Indian Ocean
Describe how Islam spread to East Africa through trade and intermarriage
Analyze the multicultural nature of Swahili coastal cities with their diverse populations

sub_topics.name: Great Zimbabwe
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the impressive stone city in southeastern Africa and its trading kingdom.
example_tasks: Describe the massive stone walls and structures of Great Zimbabwe built without mortar
Explain how Great Zimbabwe controlled trade routes between the interior gold fields and coastal ports
Analyze archaeological evidence of Great Zimbabwe's wealth and connections to distant places
Evaluate theories about why Great Zimbabwe was eventually abandoned

sub_topics.name: Diverse African Societies and Cultures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the variety of political systems, social structures, and cultural practices across Africa.

sub_topics.name: Political Organization in African Societies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining different forms of government from centralized kingdoms to stateless societies.
example_tasks: Compare centralized kingdoms like Kongo to decentralized societies organized by kinship and age groups
Describe the role of kinship and lineage in organizing many African societies
Explain how age-grade systems functioned in some African cultures
Analyze the diversity of political systems across Africa rather than viewing African politics as uniform

sub_topics.name: African Art and Cultural Achievements
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about African artistic traditions, oral literature, and cultural practices.
example_tasks: Describe the sophisticated bronze and brass sculptures of Benin and Ife civilizations
Explain the role of masks and sculpture in African religious and cultural ceremonies
Analyze the importance of oral tradition, including proverbs, folktales, and epic poems
Describe African musical traditions and the role of drums and other instruments in community life

sub_topics.name: Iron Technology and Agricultural Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how iron tools transformed African societies and enabled agricultural expansion.
example_tasks: Describe the spread of iron-working technology across sub-Saharan Africa
Explain how iron tools improved agricultural productivity and allowed clearing of forests
Analyze the Bantu migrations and the spread of agriculture and iron technology across central and southern Africa
Evaluate the impact of agricultural surplus on the development of trade and specialized crafts

name: Pre-Columbian Civilizations of the Americas
short_description: Students examine the major civilizations that developed in the Americas before European contact, including the Maya, Aztec, and Inca empires, as well as diverse Native American societies across North America.

sub_topics.name: Maya Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the achievements of the Maya in mathematics, astronomy, writing, and architecture in Mesoamerica.

sub_topics.name: Maya Political Organization and City-States
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Maya cities like Tikal and Copán and their independent rule.
example_tasks: Describe the political organization of Maya civilization as independent city-states rather than a unified empire
Explain the role of Maya kings as both political rulers and religious leaders who claimed divine descent
Identify major Maya cities and their locations in present-day Mexico, Guatemala, Belize, and Honduras
Analyze how Maya city-states cooperated and competed through trade, alliances, and warfare

sub_topics.name: Maya Mathematics, Astronomy, and Calendar
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Maya scientific and mathematical innovations.
example_tasks: Explain the Maya number system including their use of zero and place value
Describe Maya astronomical observations and accurate predictions of eclipses and planetary movements
Analyze the complexity of the Maya calendar system with its 260-day and 365-day cycles
Evaluate Maya achievements in mathematics and astronomy compared to other ancient civilizations

sub_topics.name: Maya Writing and Cultural Achievements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Maya hieroglyphic writing and artistic accomplishments.
example_tasks: Describe Maya hieroglyphic writing as one of the most sophisticated writing systems in the ancient Americas
Explain what scholars have learned from Maya codices (folding books) that survived Spanish destruction
Analyze Maya architecture, including pyramids, palaces, and ball courts
Describe the Maya ball game and its religious and political significance

sub_topics.name: Maya Decline and Transformation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining theories about the collapse of Classic Maya civilization.
example_tasks: Describe the mysterious collapse of southern Maya cities during the 9th century
Analyze theories for Maya decline: drought, warfare, environmental degradation, overpopulation
Explain that Maya people continued to live in the region and that Maya civilization transformed rather than disappeared
Describe the persistence of Maya culture and language to the present day

sub_topics.name: Aztec (Mexica) Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Studying the powerful empire that dominated central Mexico from its capital at Tenochtitlan.

sub_topics.name: Rise of the Aztec Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the Mexica people built a powerful empire through military conquest and alliances.
example_tasks: Describe the Aztec origin story and their migration to the Valley of Mexico
Explain how the Aztecs founded Tenochtitlan on an island in Lake Texcoco in 1325
Analyze how the Aztecs built their empire through the Triple Alliance and conquest of neighboring peoples
Describe the tributary system where conquered peoples paid tribute to the Aztec emperor

sub_topics.name: Tenochtitlan: The Aztec Capital
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the impressive city and its engineering achievements.
example_tasks: Describe the size and sophistication of Tenochtitlan, one of the world's largest cities in 1500
Explain the engineering of chinampas (floating gardens) for intensive agriculture
Analyze the city's system of causeways, canals, and aqueducts
Describe the Great Temple (Templo Mayor) at the center of Tenochtitlan and its religious significance

sub_topics.name: Aztec Society and Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Aztec social hierarchy, education, and cultural practices.
example_tasks: Describe the Aztec social hierarchy from the emperor to nobles, commoners, and slaves
Explain the importance of military achievement in Aztec society for social advancement
Analyze Aztec education systems that trained children for their future roles
Describe Aztec art, including sculpture, featherwork, and codices (pictorial manuscripts)

sub_topics.name: Aztec Religion and Human Sacrifice
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Aztec polytheistic beliefs and controversial ritual practices.
example_tasks: Describe major Aztec gods including Huitzilopochtli (war/sun god) and Quetzalcoatl (feathered serpent)
Explain Aztec beliefs about the need for human sacrifice to sustain the sun and prevent cosmic disaster
Analyze how human sacrifice related to Aztec warfare and the capture of prisoners
Evaluate different historical perspectives on the extent and meaning of Aztec human sacrifice

sub_topics.name: Inca Civilization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the largest empire in pre-Columbian America, stretching along the Andes Mountains of South America.

sub_topics.name: Formation and Expansion of the Inca Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the Inca built and administered their vast empire.
example_tasks: Describe the location and extent of the Inca Empire along the western coast of South America
Explain how Pachacuti expanded the empire dramatically in the 15th century
Analyze Inca strategies for incorporating conquered peoples into the empire
Describe the mit'a system of labor taxation used to build public works

sub_topics.name: Inca Government and Administration
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the centralized bureaucracy and efficient administration of the empire.
example_tasks: Explain the role of the Sapa Inca as absolute ruler considered divine
Describe how the Inca divided their empire into four quarters administered by officials
Analyze the system of quipu (knotted strings) used for record-keeping without a writing system
Evaluate the efficiency of Inca administration in controlling such a large and diverse empire

sub_topics.name: Inca Engineering and Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Examining impressive Inca construction techniques and infrastructure.
example_tasks: Describe the extensive road system connecting the Inca Empire, totaling thousands of miles
Explain Inca stone masonry techniques that fit massive stones together without mortar
Analyze the architecture of Machu Picchu and theories about its purpose
Describe Inca agricultural terracing and irrigation systems in the challenging Andean environment

sub_topics.name: Inca Economy and Social Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Inca society was organized and the economy functioned.
example_tasks: Describe the Inca social hierarchy with the Sapa Inca at the top and commoners at the bottom
Explain the ayllu (extended family group) as the basic unit of Inca society
Analyze the Inca economy based on reciprocal labor rather than money or markets
Describe how the government controlled production and distribution of goods, including food storage in case of famine

sub_topics.name: Native American Societies in North America
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the diverse cultures and ways of life of indigenous peoples across North America before European contact.
