sub_topics.name: Southwest Cultures: Pueblo and Others
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about agricultural societies adapted to arid environments.
example_tasks: Describe the Ancestral Puebloans (Anasazi) and their cliff dwellings like Mesa Verde
Explain agricultural techniques including irrigation that allowed farming in the Southwest desert
Analyze the pueblo architecture and its advantages for defense and climate control
Describe the sophisticated pottery and basket weaving of Southwest peoples

sub_topics.name: Eastern Woodlands Peoples
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding societies living in the forests of eastern North America.
example_tasks: Describe the Iroquois Confederacy and its system of representative government
Explain the 'Three Sisters' agricultural system (corn, beans, squash) practiced in the Eastern Woodlands
Analyze the political organization of the Iroquois League and its influence on later democratic ideas
Describe housing styles like longhouses used by Iroquois peoples

sub_topics.name: Great Plains Peoples
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about nomadic and semi-nomadic societies of the plains region.
example_tasks: Describe the lifestyle of Plains peoples and their dependence on buffalo herds before European contact
Explain how different Plains groups lived as nomadic hunters or sedentary farmers
Analyze how the horse (introduced later by Europeans) transformed Plains Indian culture
Describe the tipi as portable housing suited to nomadic life

sub_topics.name: Pacific Northwest Coastal Cultures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding societies that developed rich cultures based on marine resources.
example_tasks: Describe how abundant salmon and other resources allowed Northwest peoples to develop complex societies
Explain the potlatch ceremony and its role in demonstrating wealth and status
Analyze totem poles as artistic and cultural expressions telling family histories
Describe the sophisticated woodworking and carving traditions of Pacific Northwest peoples

sub_topics.name: Mound Builders: Cahokia and Mississippian Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the complex societies that built massive earthen mounds in the Mississippi Valley.
example_tasks: Describe Cahokia as the largest pre-Columbian city north of Mexico with a population in the tens of thousands
Explain the purposes of different types of mounds (burial, temple, residential)
Analyze evidence of Cahokia's extensive trade networks reaching across North America
Evaluate theories about why Cahokia and other Mississippian cities were eventually abandoned

name: Renaissance and Reformation
short_description: Students analyze the cultural rebirth and intellectual transformation of the Renaissance, the religious upheaval of the Protestant Reformation, and the Scientific Revolution's challenge to traditional authority and worldviews.

sub_topics.name: The Italian Renaissance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the revival of classical learning, humanism, and artistic achievement in Italy.

sub_topics.name: Origins and Characteristics of the Renaissance
sub_topics.short_description: Learning why the Renaissance began in Italy and its defining features.
example_tasks: Explain why the Renaissance began in Italian city-states like Florence, Venice, and Milan
Describe how Italy's urban wealth, classical heritage, and trade connections fostered cultural rebirth
Define 'Renaissance' (rebirth) and explain what was being reborn (interest in classical Greco-Roman culture)
Analyze the role of wealthy patrons like the Medici family in supporting Renaissance artists and scholars

sub_topics.name: Renaissance Humanism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the intellectual movement emphasizing human potential and classical studies.
example_tasks: Define humanism and its focus on human achievement, dignity, and potential rather than solely religious concerns
Explain the humanist emphasis on studying classical texts, rhetoric, history, and moral philosophy
Describe the shift from medieval focus on the afterlife to Renaissance celebration of earthly existence
Analyze how humanism influenced education with emphasis on liberal arts and classical languages

sub_topics.name: Renaissance Art and Artists
sub_topics.short_description: Examining revolutionary artistic techniques and the works of master artists.
example_tasks: Describe major innovations in Renaissance art: perspective, realism, use of light and shadow (chiaroscuro), human anatomy
Analyze Leonardo da Vinci's works and his embodiment of the 'Renaissance man' ideal
Describe Michelangelo's sculptures (David, Pietà) and Sistine Chapel ceiling paintings
Explain Raphael's contributions including his idealized figures and balanced compositions
Compare Renaissance art's realism and focus on humans to medieval art's stylized, religious focus

sub_topics.name: Renaissance Literature and Political Thought
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about writers who explored human nature and political power.
example_tasks: Describe Machiavelli's 'The Prince' and his realistic analysis of political power
Explain the controversial advice in Machiavelli's work about rulers prioritizing effectiveness over morality
Analyze other Renaissance literature including Petrarch's sonnets and Dante's Divine Comedy
Compare Renaissance secular literature to medieval religious texts

sub_topics.name: The Northern Renaissance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Renaissance ideas spread north of the Alps and took on distinct characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Northern Renaissance
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how the Renaissance manifested differently in Northern Europe.
example_tasks: Describe how the Northern Renaissance retained stronger religious focus compared to Italian Renaissance
Explain the emphasis on social reform and Christian piety in Northern humanist thought
Analyze the importance of the printing press in spreading Renaissance ideas northward
Compare Italian Renaissance focus on classical paganism to Northern focus on Christian reform

sub_topics.name: Northern Renaissance Artists
sub_topics.short_description: Examining artistic achievements in Flanders, Germany, and other northern regions.
example_tasks: Describe Jan van Eyck's innovations in oil painting and realistic detail
Analyze Albrecht Dürer's works combining German precision with Italian Renaissance techniques
Explain Pieter Bruegel's paintings of peasant life and their social commentary
Compare Northern Renaissance art (detailed realism, everyday scenes, religious themes) to Italian Renaissance art

sub_topics.name: Erasmus and Christian Humanism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the call for church reform through education and return to early Christian sources.
example_tasks: Describe Erasmus's critique of church corruption and call for simple Christian piety
Explain Erasmus's use of satire in works like 'The Praise of Folly' to criticize society and church
Analyze Erasmus's Greek New Testament and its challenge to traditional Latin Vulgate
Evaluate how Erasmus's calls for reform influenced but differed from the Protestant Reformation

sub_topics.name: The Protestant Reformation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the religious revolution that shattered Christian unity and transformed European society.

sub_topics.name: Causes of the Reformation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the problems in the Catholic Church that sparked reform movements.
example_tasks: Describe corruption in the Catholic Church including simony (selling church offices) and nepotism
Explain the sale of indulgences and why this practice angered reformers
Analyze how printing press, literacy, and nationalism contributed to the Reformation's spread
Evaluate the role of Renaissance humanism in questioning church authority and practices

sub_topics.name: Martin Luther and the German Reformation
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Luther's challenge to Catholic doctrine and the beginning of Protestantism.
example_tasks: Describe Martin Luther's spiritual crisis and his conclusion about salvation by faith alone
Explain the Ninety-Five Theses (1517) and Luther's specific criticisms of indulgences
Analyze Luther's key theological positions: sola fide (faith alone), sola scriptura (scripture alone), priesthood of all believers
Describe Luther's refusal to recant at the Diet of Worms and his subsequent protection by German princes
Evaluate the political and social factors that allowed Lutheranism to survive and spread in Germany

sub_topics.name: Spread of Protestant Ideas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Protestant movements developed in different regions with local characteristics.
example_tasks: Describe John Calvin's theology including predestination and his strict moral code
Explain the establishment of Calvinist theocracy in Geneva, Switzerland
Analyze the English Reformation and how it differed from the German Reformation (political rather than theological initially)
Describe the formation of the Anglican Church under Henry VIII and Elizabeth I
Explain the development of other Protestant groups like Anabaptists and their beliefs

sub_topics.name: Catholic Reformation (Counter-Reformation)
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the Catholic Church's response to Protestant challenges through reform and reaffirmation.
example_tasks: Describe reforms initiated by the Council of Trent (1545-1563) to address corruption
Explain how the Council of Trent reaffirmed traditional Catholic doctrines against Protestant beliefs
Analyze the role of the Jesuits (Society of Jesus) in spreading Catholicism and combating Protestantism
Describe the Roman Inquisition and Index of Forbidden Books as tools to prevent spread of Protestant ideas
Evaluate whether the Catholic Reformation was primarily defensive reaction or genuine internal reform

sub_topics.name: Religious Wars and Conflicts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the violence and warfare sparked by religious divisions.
example_tasks: Describe the devastating Thirty Years' War (1618-1648) as a religious and political conflict
Explain the Peace of Westphalia (1648) and the principle of cuius regio, eius religio (ruler's religion determines the religion of the region)
Analyze the French Wars of Religion including the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre
Evaluate the long-term impact of religious divisions on European politics and society

sub_topics.name: The Scientific Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the transformation in scientific thinking that challenged traditional authority and established new methods of investigation.

sub_topics.name: Development of Scientific Method
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the new approach to investigating nature through observation and experimentation.
example_tasks: Describe the key steps of the scientific method: observation, hypothesis, experimentation, conclusion
Explain Francis Bacon's emphasis on empirical observation and inductive reasoning
Analyze René Descartes' contributions to deductive reasoning and systematic doubt
Compare the scientific method to medieval reliance on ancient authorities and religious texts

sub_topics.name: Revolution in Astronomy
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how new discoveries overturned the geocentric model of the universe.
example_tasks: Describe Copernicus's heliocentric theory and why it was controversial
Explain Galileo's telescopic observations that supported the heliocentric model
Analyze Galileo's conflict with the Catholic Church and his forced recantation
Describe Kepler's laws of planetary motion and Newton's law of universal gravitation
Evaluate how astronomy challenged religious and philosophical assumptions about Earth's place in the universe

sub_topics.name: Advances in Medicine and Anatomy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how direct observation improved medical knowledge.
example_tasks: Describe Andreas Vesalius's pioneering work in human anatomy based on dissection
Explain William Harvey's discovery of blood circulation
Analyze how these discoveries challenged ancient medical authorities like Galen
Evaluate the resistance to new medical ideas from traditional physicians

sub_topics.name: Impact of the Scientific Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the broader cultural and intellectual consequences of scientific thinking.
example_tasks: Explain how the Scientific Revolution challenged traditional sources of authority (church, ancient texts)
Describe the founding of scientific societies and academies to share and verify discoveries
Analyze how scientific thinking promoted ideas about progress and human ability to understand nature
Evaluate connections between the Scientific Revolution and later Enlightenment thinking

name: Age of Exploration and European Expansion
short_description: Students examine the motivations, technologies, and consequences of European exploration, analyzing the Columbian Exchange, establishment of trading empires, and the devastating impact of European diseases and conquest on indigenous peoples.

sub_topics.name: Motives and Causes of European Exploration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Europeans sought new routes to Asia and explored unknown territories.

sub_topics.name: Economic Motivations: God, Gold, and Glory
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the desire for wealth, trade routes, and prestige that drove exploration.
example_tasks: Explain the Three Gs of exploration: God (spread Christianity), Gold (wealth and trade), Glory (national prestige and personal fame)
Describe why Europeans sought direct sea routes to Asia for spices and other luxury goods
Analyze how the fall of Constantinople (1453) motivated Europeans to find alternative routes to Asia
Evaluate which motive (economic, religious, or political) was most important in driving exploration

sub_topics.name: Technological Advances Enabling Exploration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the navigational tools and ship designs that made long voyages possible.
example_tasks: Describe key technologies: compass, astrolabe, improved maps, and better shipbuilding
Explain the advantages of the caravel ship design for long-distance ocean voyages
Analyze how knowledge of wind patterns and ocean currents aided navigation
Evaluate how advances in cartography (mapmaking) both enabled and resulted from exploration

sub_topics.name: Portuguese Exploration of Africa and Asia
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Portugal's pioneering role in exploration and establishment of a trading empire.

sub_topics.name: Prince Henry the Navigator and African Exploration
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Portugal's systematic exploration of the African coast.
example_tasks: Describe Prince Henry's sponsorship of exploration and establishment of a navigation school
Explain Portuguese motivations: finding sea route to Asia, accessing African gold, spreading Christianity
Analyze how Portuguese established trading posts along the African coast
Describe the Portuguese slave trade from West Africa and its expansion

sub_topics.name: Portuguese Route to Asia and Trading Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Portugal reached India and established a maritime empire.
example_tasks: Describe Bartolomeu Dias's voyage around the southern tip of Africa (Cape of Good Hope) in 1488
Explain Vasco da Gama's successful voyage to India in 1498 and its significance
Analyze Portuguese establishment of trading posts in India, Southeast Asia, and East Asia
Evaluate how Portugal's small population limited its ability to establish large colonies versus trading posts

sub_topics.name: Spanish Exploration and Conquest of the Americas
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Spain's sponsorship of Columbus and subsequent conquest of vast American territories.

sub_topics.name: Columbus and the 'Discovery' of the Americas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Columbus's voyages and their world-changing consequences.
example_tasks: Describe Columbus's goal of reaching Asia by sailing west and why he believed this was possible
Explain why Queen Isabella of Spain agreed to sponsor Columbus's voyage in 1492
Analyze Columbus's four voyages and his continued belief he had reached Asia
Evaluate the term 'discovery' and why it's problematic given millions already lived in the Americas
Describe the Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) dividing newly discovered lands between Spain and Portugal

sub_topics.name: Spanish Conquistadors and Conquest
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the Spanish conquest of major American civilizations.
example_tasks: Describe Hernán Cortés's conquest of the Aztec Empire (1519-1521) with only a few hundred soldiers
Explain factors that enabled Spanish success: guns, horses, steel weapons, indigenous allies, and disease
Analyze Francisco Pizarro's conquest of the Inca Empire in the 1530s
Describe the encomienda system that granted conquistadors control over indigenous labor
Evaluate the brutality of Spanish conquest and the moral debates it sparked (Las Casas vs. Sepúlveda)

sub_topics.name: Spanish Colonial Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Spain administered its vast American territories.
example_tasks: Describe the organization of Spanish colonies into viceroyalties (New Spain, Peru, etc.)
Explain the social hierarchy in Spanish colonies with peninsulares (Spanish-born) at the top
Analyze the role of Catholic missions in converting indigenous peoples
Describe the extraction of silver and gold from American mines using forced indigenous labor

sub_topics.name: The Columbian Exchange
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the massive exchange of plants, animals, diseases, and ideas between hemispheres.

sub_topics.name: Exchange of Plants, Animals, and Foods
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what crossed the Atlantic and transformed diets and agriculture globally.
example_tasks: Identify major foods that traveled from the Americas to Europe/Africa/Asia: corn, potatoes, tomatoes, cacao, tobacco
Identify major items that traveled from Europe/Africa/Asia to Americas: wheat, sugar, horses, cattle, pigs
Explain how the potato and corn increased food supplies and populations in Europe and Asia
Analyze how the exchange of crops and animals transformed agriculture and diets on both sides of the Atlantic
Describe the environmental impact of introducing new species to different ecosystems

sub_topics.name: Disease Exchange and Demographic Catastrophe
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the devastating impact of Old World diseases on indigenous American populations.
example_tasks: Describe how European diseases (smallpox, measles, typhus, influenza) decimated Native American populations
Explain why Native Americans had no immunity to these diseases while Europeans had built up resistance
Analyze estimates that 50-90% of indigenous populations died within a century of contact
Evaluate how disease was the most significant factor in Spanish conquest success
Describe the theory that syphilis may have traveled from Americas to Europe as part of the exchange

sub_topics.name: Cultural and Technological Exchanges
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the exchange of ideas, technologies, and cultural practices.
example_tasks: Describe how European horses transformed Native American cultures, particularly on the Great Plains
Explain the spread of Christianity to the Americas through missions and forced conversion
Analyze how European concepts of land ownership conflicted with indigenous communal land use
Evaluate both positive and devastating aspects of the Columbian Exchange for different groups

sub_topics.name: English, French, and Dutch Exploration
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how other European powers joined the competition for colonies and trade routes.

sub_topics.name: Search for the Northwest Passage
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about attempts to find a northern route through North America to Asia.
example_tasks: Explain why England and France sought a Northwest Passage through North America
Describe voyages of explorers like John Cabot, Jacques Cartier, and Henry Hudson
Analyze why the search for the Northwest Passage failed but led to claims in North America
Evaluate how these explorations established territorial claims for future colonization

sub_topics.name: Joint-Stock Companies and Trading Empires
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how private companies established trading networks and colonies.
example_tasks: Describe the formation of joint-stock companies like the Dutch East India Company and English East India Company
Explain how these companies combined private investment with government-granted monopolies
Analyze Dutch success in controlling the spice trade in Southeast Asia
Compare the Dutch/English model of trading companies to Spanish/Portuguese direct government control

sub_topics.name: Impact on Indigenous Peoples
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the profound and often devastating consequences of European contact for native populations.

sub_topics.name: Population Collapse and Its Causes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the demographic catastrophe that befell indigenous peoples.
example_tasks: Describe the multiple causes of indigenous population decline: disease, warfare, forced labor, famine
Analyze regional variations in population loss across different parts of the Americas
Explain how population loss disrupted indigenous societies, agriculture, and culture
Evaluate long-term demographic consequences that lasted for centuries

sub_topics.name: Indigenous Resistance and Adaptation
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how native peoples resisted, adapted to, and sometimes cooperated with Europeans.
example_tasks: Describe examples of indigenous military resistance to European conquest
Explain how some indigenous groups formed alliances with Europeans against rival native groups
Analyze indigenous adoption of European technologies like horses and metal tools
Evaluate the survival and persistence of indigenous cultures despite colonization pressures

sub_topics.name: Cultural and Religious Suppression
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding European efforts to eliminate indigenous religions, languages, and cultures.
example_tasks: Describe Spanish destruction of Aztec and Maya codices and temples
Explain forced conversion to Christianity and suppression of indigenous religions
Analyze the encomienda and later hacienda systems that exploited indigenous labor
Evaluate Bartolomé de Las Casas's defense of indigenous peoples and advocacy for their rights

name: Colonial Americas and Atlantic World
short_description: Students examine the establishment of European colonies in North and South America, the development of the Atlantic slave trade, triangular trade networks, and the emergence of distinct colonial societies and economies.

sub_topics.name: Spanish Colonial System in the Americas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Spanish colonial administration, economy, and society in detail.

sub_topics.name: Spanish Colonial Government and Administration
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how Spain governed its vast American empire.
example_tasks: Describe the Council of the Indies and its role in overseeing Spanish colonies from Spain
Explain the viceroyalty system dividing colonies into large administrative regions
Analyze the role of audiencias (courts) in colonial governance
Describe how Spain maintained tight control over colonial trade and economics through mercantilism

sub_topics.name: Colonial Economy: Mining and Agriculture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Spain extracted wealth from its colonies.
example_tasks: Describe the importance of silver mining, particularly the Potosí mine in Bolivia
Explain the mita system of forced indigenous labor in mines
Analyze the hacienda system of large agricultural estates
Evaluate how the flow of American silver affected the Spanish and global economy

sub_topics.name: Spanish Colonial Social Hierarchy and Caste System
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the complex social stratification in Spanish colonies based on race and birth.
example_tasks: Describe the caste system hierarchy: peninsulares, creoles, mestizos, mulattoes, indigenous peoples, enslaved Africans
Explain why peninsulares (born in Spain) held the highest positions despite being outnumbered
Analyze resentment among creoles (American-born Spanish) over being excluded from top positions
Describe how racial mixing created complex categories and social mobility challenges

sub_topics.name: British Colonies in North America
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the establishment and development of English colonies that became the United States.

sub_topics.name: Early English Settlements: Jamestown and Plymouth
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the first permanent English colonies and their struggles.
example_tasks: Describe the founding of Jamestown in 1607 and the colonists' initial struggles with disease, starvation, and conflict
Explain how tobacco cultivation saved Jamestown's economy and attracted more settlers
Analyze the Pilgrims' founding of Plymouth in 1620 and their motivations for religious freedom
Compare the economic motivations of Jamestown to the religious motivations of Plymouth

sub_topics.name: Regional Differences: New England, Middle, and Southern Colonies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how geography and purpose created distinct colonial regions.
example_tasks: Describe New England colonies' economy based on fishing, shipbuilding, trade, and small farms
Explain the Middle Colonies' diversity and economy based on grain farming and trade
Analyze Southern colonies' plantation economy based on tobacco, rice, and indigo with enslaved labor
Compare Puritan religious dominance in New England to religious diversity in Middle Colonies
Create a chart comparing the three colonial regions in terms of economy, society, and religion

sub_topics.name: Development of Colonial Self-Government
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about representative assemblies and growing colonial autonomy.
example_tasks: Describe the Virginia House of Burgesses (1619) as the first representative assembly in the colonies
Explain the Mayflower Compact as an early example of self-government and social contract
Analyze how colonial assemblies gradually gained power over taxation and legislation
Evaluate the principle of 'no taxation without representation' that developed in colonial politics

sub_topics.name: Relations Between Colonists and Native Americans
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cooperation, conflict, and changing power dynamics.
example_tasks: Describe early cooperation between colonists and Native Americans, including trade and the first Thanksgiving
Explain conflicts over land, including King Philip's War (1675-1676) in New England
Analyze how European diseases, warfare, and land loss devastated Native American populations
Evaluate different colonial approaches to Native Americans (Spanish missions, French trade partnerships, English displacement)

sub_topics.name: French and Dutch Colonies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining other European colonial ventures in North America and the Caribbean.

sub_topics.name: New France and the Fur Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding French colonization focused on trade rather than large-scale settlement.
example_tasks: Describe the French colony of New France, including Quebec and the St. Lawrence River region
Explain the French focus on fur trading and alliance-building with Native American tribes
Analyze why New France remained sparsely populated compared to British colonies
Describe French exploration and claims from Canada through the Great Lakes to Louisiana

sub_topics.name: Dutch Colony of New Netherland
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Dutch colonization and trade in North America.
example_tasks: Describe the Dutch colony of New Netherland centered on the Hudson River and New Amsterdam (later New York)
Explain the Dutch West India Company's role in establishing the colony for trade
Analyze why the Dutch colony was religiously tolerant and ethnically diverse
Describe the English takeover of New Netherland in 1664

sub_topics.name: Atlantic Slave Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the forced migration of millions of Africans and the development of the plantation slavery system.

sub_topics.name: Origins and Growth of the Atlantic Slave Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Europeans turned to African slavery for colonial labor.
example_tasks: Explain why Europeans initially used enslaved Africans: indigenous population decline, immunity to European diseases, experience with tropical agriculture
Describe the growth of the slave trade from the 1500s through the 1800s
Analyze the role of European, African, and American participants in the slave trade
Evaluate estimates that 12-15 million Africans were forcibly transported to the Americas

sub_topics.name: The Middle Passage
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the horrific ocean voyage that enslaved Africans endured.
example_tasks: Describe the brutal conditions of the Middle Passage: overcrowding, disease, violence, inadequate food and water
Explain that approximately 15-20% of enslaved Africans died during the voyage
Analyze resistance by enslaved people during the Middle Passage, including rebellions and suicide
Evaluate the Middle Passage as one of history's greatest atrocities and forced migrations

sub_topics.name: Impact on Africa
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the slave trade affected African societies and economies.
example_tasks: Describe how the slave trade disrupted African societies and economies
Explain the role of African kingdoms and merchants in capturing and selling enslaved people
Analyze how the slave trade increased warfare between African states competing for captives
Evaluate long-term demographic, economic, and social impacts on African societies

sub_topics.name: Slavery in the Americas
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the harsh conditions and resistance of enslaved people in colonial plantations.
example_tasks: Describe the brutal working conditions on sugar, tobacco, rice, and cotton plantations
Explain slave codes that legally defined enslaved people as property with no rights
Analyze various forms of resistance: work slowdowns, sabotage, escape, rebellion
Describe major slave revolts like the Stono Rebellion (1739) and Haitian Revolution (1791-1804)
Evaluate how slavery shaped colonial economies and social structures

sub_topics.name: Triangular Trade and Atlantic Economy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the interconnected trading system linking Europe, Africa, and the Americas.

sub_topics.name: Routes and Goods of Triangular Trade
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the three-leg trading system across the Atlantic.
example_tasks: Describe the three legs of triangular trade: Europe to Africa (manufactured goods), Africa to Americas (enslaved people), Americas to Europe (sugar, tobacco, cotton)
Explain how each leg of the triangle was profitable for European traders and merchants
Analyze how mercantilism motivated colonial powers to control this trade
Create a diagram showing the flow of goods and people in the triangular trade system

sub_topics.name: Mercantilism and Colonial Economic Policy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the economic theory that colonies existed to benefit the mother country.
example_tasks: Define mercantilism and its goal of accumulating gold and silver through favorable trade balances
Explain how mother countries restricted colonial trade to benefit themselves
Describe Navigation Acts and similar laws controlling colonial commerce
Analyze colonial resentment of mercantilist restrictions on their economic freedom

sub_topics.name: Colonial Culture and Society
sub_topics.short_description: Examining social structures, cultural exchange, and daily life in colonial societies.

sub_topics.name: Social Hierarchies in Colonial Societies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding class, race, and status in different colonial regions.
example_tasks: Describe social hierarchies in different colonial regions based on race, wealth, and birth
Explain the emergence of new racial and ethnic identities through mixing of European, African, and indigenous peoples
Analyze opportunities and restrictions for different social groups (women, free blacks, indentured servants, enslaved people)
Compare social mobility in different colonial systems

sub_topics.name: Cultural Exchange and Creolization
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the blending of European, African, and indigenous cultures.
example_tasks: Describe how African, European, and indigenous cultures blended in food, music, religion, and language
Explain the development of creole languages and syncretic religions
Analyze African cultural retention and adaptation in the Americas
Evaluate the creation of new, distinctly American cultures different from any single source

name: Absolute Monarchies and Early Revolutions
short_description: Students examine the age of absolutism in Europe, analyzing how monarchs claimed unlimited power, the resistance movements that challenged royal authority, and the English revolutions that established constitutional limitations on government.

sub_topics.name: The Age of Absolutism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the theory and practice of absolute monarchy in European states.

sub_topics.name: Theory of Divine Right of Kings
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the ideological justification for absolute royal power.
example_tasks: Define divine right of kings as the belief that monarchs received their authority directly from God
Explain how divine right theory made challenging the king equivalent to challenging God
Analyze how monarchs used divine right claims to justify absolute power and resist limitations
Compare divine right theory to earlier medieval ideas about shared power between kings and nobles

sub_topics.name: Louis XIV and Absolutism in France
sub_topics.short_description: Examining France under the Sun King as the model of absolute monarchy.
example_tasks: Describe Louis XIV's statement 'L'état, c'est moi' (I am the state) and what it reveals about his power
Explain how Louis XIV centralized power by weakening the nobility and controlling the government
Analyze the construction and purpose of the Palace of Versailles as a symbol and tool of royal power
Describe how Louis XIV controlled the French economy through mercantilism and his finance minister Colbert
Evaluate the costs and benefits of Louis XIV's absolutism for France

sub_topics.name: Absolutism in Other European States
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding absolute rule in Spain, Austria, Prussia, and Russia.
example_tasks: Describe Philip II of Spain and his centralized control of a global empire
Explain how the Habsburgs of Austria consolidated power over diverse territories
Analyze Peter the Great's westernization and modernization of Russia while maintaining absolute rule
Compare different models of absolutism across European states

sub_topics.name: English Civil War
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the conflict between Parliament and King Charles I that led to civil war and execution of the monarch.

sub_topics.name: Causes of the English Civil War
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the religious, political, and economic tensions that led to war.
example_tasks: Describe conflicts between Charles I and Parliament over taxation and royal authority
Explain religious tensions between the Anglican Church, Puritans, and Catholics
Analyze Charles I's attempt to rule without Parliament for eleven years (1629-1640)
Evaluate how Charles I's belief in divine right conflicted with Parliament's claims to power

sub_topics.name: The Civil War and Oliver Cromwell
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the military conflict between Royalists and Parliamentarians.
example_tasks: Describe the division between Cavaliers (supporters of the king) and Roundheads (supporters of Parliament)
Explain Oliver Cromwell's role as military leader of the parliamentary forces
Analyze the trial and execution of Charles I in 1649 as an unprecedented act
Describe Cromwell's rule as Lord Protector and his establishment of a Puritan commonwealth

sub_topics.name: Restoration of the Monarchy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the return of the Stuart kings after Cromwell's death.
example_tasks: Explain why the monarchy was restored in 1660 with Charles II after Cromwell's death
Describe the reign of James II and fears of Catholic absolutism
Analyze tensions between king and Parliament that continued after the Restoration
Evaluate whether the English Civil War permanently changed the balance of power

sub_topics.name: The Glorious Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining England's bloodless revolution that established constitutional monarchy and parliamentary supremacy.

sub_topics.name: Causes and Events of 1688
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Parliament invited William and Mary to take the throne.
example_tasks: Describe James II's pro-Catholic policies that alarmed Protestant Parliament
Explain why Parliament invited William of Orange and Mary to invade England
Analyze why James II fled without fighting, making this a 'bloodless' revolution
Evaluate the significance of Parliament choosing the monarch rather than accepting hereditary succession

sub_topics.name: English Bill of Rights (1689)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the document that limited royal power and established parliamentary rights.
example_tasks: Describe key provisions of the English Bill of Rights: regular parliaments, free elections, freedom of speech in Parliament, no taxation without parliamentary consent
Explain how the Bill of Rights established constitutional monarchy with real power in Parliament
Analyze specific rights protected, such as the right to petition and prohibition of cruel punishment
Compare the English Bill of Rights to later American Bill of Rights and identify influences

sub_topics.name: Significance and Legacy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the long-term impact on British government and political thought.
example_tasks: Evaluate how the Glorious Revolution established the principle that government power comes from consent of the governed
Explain John Locke's political philosophy and how the Glorious Revolution reflected his ideas
Analyze how the Glorious Revolution influenced later democratic revolutions, especially the American Revolution
Describe the development of cabinet government and the prime minister system after 1688

sub_topics.name: Comparing Absolutism and Constitutionalism
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the contrast between unlimited royal power and government limited by law and representative bodies.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Each System
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the defining features of absolute versus constitutional government.
example_tasks: Create a comparison chart showing key differences between absolutism and constitutionalism
Explain how absolutism concentrated power in the monarch while constitutionalism divided it
Analyze the role of law: absolute monarchs claimed to be above law while constitutional systems subjected rulers to law
Compare France under Louis XIV (absolutism) to England after 1688 (constitutionalism)

sub_topics.name: Long-term Political Development
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating which system proved more stable and influential.
example_tasks: Analyze why constitutionalism proved more adaptable to changing circumstances
Explain how absolutism eventually collapsed in violent revolutions (France, Russia)
Evaluate the influence of English constitutionalism on American and other democratic systems
Describe the gradual spread of constitutional limitations on government power

name: The Enlightenment
short_description: Students explore the Age of Reason, examining Enlightenment thinkers' emphasis on reason, science, individual rights, and social progress, and analyzing how these ideas challenged traditional authority and inspired political revolutions.

sub_topics.name: Origins and Characteristics of the Enlightenment
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the intellectual movement that emphasized reason, science, and progress.

sub_topics.name: Intellectual Foundations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning what preceded and enabled the Enlightenment.
example_tasks: Explain how the Scientific Revolution provided a model for using reason to understand the world
Describe how the printing press enabled rapid spread of new ideas
Analyze the growth of literacy and educated middle class interested in new ideas
Evaluate the role of salons and coffeehouses as venues for intellectual discussion

sub_topics.name: Core Enlightenment Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the key beliefs that defined Enlightenment thinking.
example_tasks: Define the Enlightenment emphasis on reason as the primary source of authority and legitimacy
Explain the belief in natural law governing human affairs, discoverable through reason
Describe faith in progress and the perfectibility of human society
Analyze the emphasis on individual rights and human dignity
Evaluate how these ideas challenged traditional sources of authority (monarchy, church, tradition)

sub_topics.name: Major Enlightenment Philosophers
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the ideas of key thinkers who shaped Enlightenment thought.

sub_topics.name: John Locke: Natural Rights and Social Contract
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Locke's influential political philosophy.
example_tasks: Explain Locke's concept of natural rights: life, liberty, and property
Describe Locke's social contract theory: people agree to government to protect their rights
Analyze Locke's argument that people have the right to overthrow unjust governments
Evaluate how Locke's ideas influenced the American Declaration of Independence
Compare Locke's optimistic view of human nature to earlier pessimistic views

sub_topics.name: Montesquieu: Separation of Powers
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about checks and balances in government.
example_tasks: Describe Montesquieu's analysis of different forms of government in 'The Spirit of the Laws'
Explain his theory of separation of powers into legislative, executive, and judicial branches
Analyze how separation of powers prevents tyranny through checks and balances
Evaluate the influence of Montesquieu's ideas on the United States Constitution
Compare Montesquieu's system to absolute monarchy with concentrated power

sub_topics.name: Jean-Jacques Rousseau: Popular Sovereignty
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Rousseau's democratic philosophy and general will.
example_tasks: Explain Rousseau's famous statement that 'man is born free, and everywhere he is in chains'
Describe Rousseau's concept of the general will and popular sovereignty
Analyze Rousseau's social contract theory emphasizing direct democracy
Evaluate how Rousseau's ideas influenced the French Revolution
Compare Rousseau's emphasis on equality to Locke's emphasis on individual rights

sub_topics.name: Voltaire: Religious Tolerance and Freedom of Speech
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about criticism of church power and advocacy for civil liberties.
example_tasks: Describe Voltaire's satirical criticism of religious intolerance and church corruption
Explain Voltaire's famous statement about defending others' right to speak even when disagreeing
Analyze Voltaire's promotion of deism (belief in a creator who doesn't intervene) over organized religion
Evaluate Voltaire's influence on ideals of free speech and religious freedom

sub_topics.name: Other Enlightenment Philosophers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding contributions of additional key thinkers.
example_tasks: Describe Adam Smith's economic philosophy of free markets and the 'invisible hand' in 'The Wealth of Nations'
Explain Cesare Beccaria's arguments against torture and for fair criminal justice
Analyze Mary Wollstonecraft's 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman' as early feminist thought
Evaluate Denis Diderot's Encyclopedia as an attempt to organize and spread Enlightenment knowledge

sub_topics.name: Impact of Enlightenment Ideas
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how Enlightenment thought influenced politics, society, and culture.

sub_topics.name: Enlightened Despotism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding monarchs who claimed to rule by Enlightenment principles.
example_tasks: Define enlightened despotism as absolute rule supposedly guided by reason and serving the people
Describe reforms of enlightened despots like Frederick II of Prussia and Catherine the Great of Russia
Analyze whether these rulers genuinely embraced Enlightenment ideals or used them as propaganda
Evaluate the contradiction between enlightened principles and continued absolute power

sub_topics.name: Influence on Democratic Revolutions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how Enlightenment ideas inspired revolutionary movements.
example_tasks: Explain how Enlightenment ideas of natural rights and popular sovereignty justified revolution
Describe specific Enlightenment concepts visible in the American Declaration of Independence
Analyze how French revolutionaries drew on Enlightenment philosophy
Evaluate the transformation of philosophical ideas into political action

sub_topics.name: Social and Religious Impact
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Enlightenment challenged traditional social hierarchies and religious authority.
example_tasks: Describe the rise of religious skepticism and deism among educated elites
Explain challenges to traditional justifications for social inequality
Analyze early arguments for religious tolerance and separation of church and state
Evaluate the emergence of debates about slavery, women's rights, and education

sub_topics.name: Limitations and Criticisms of the Enlightenment
sub_topics.short_description: Examining who was excluded from Enlightenment ideals and critiques of its principles.

sub_topics.name: Who Was Left Out of Enlightenment Ideals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that Enlightenment thinkers often excluded women, non-Europeans, and the poor.
example_tasks: Analyze how most Enlightenment thinkers limited natural rights to property-owning men
Describe how many Enlightenment figures held racist views about non-European peoples
Explain how women were excluded from political participation despite talk of universal rights
Evaluate the contradiction between universal principles and exclusionary practices
Describe early critics like Mary Wollstonecraft who pointed out these contradictions

sub_topics.name: Romantic Reaction to Enlightenment
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about later criticism that reason alone was insufficient.
example_tasks: Describe the Romantic movement's emphasis on emotion, intuition, and individual creativity
Explain Romantic criticism that Enlightenment overvalued reason and undervalued feeling
Analyze Romantic appreciation for nature, tradition, and the supernatural that Enlightenment dismissed
Compare Enlightenment universalism to Romantic nationalism and appreciation of cultural diversity

name: The American Revolution
short_description: Students analyze the causes of colonial rebellion against Britain, major events of the Revolutionary War, the Declaration of Independence, the challenges of creating a new nation, and the Constitution's framework for government.

sub_topics.name: Causes of the American Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the growing tensions between Britain and its American colonies.

sub_topics.name: French and Indian War and Its Aftermath
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how this conflict changed British policy toward the colonies.
example_tasks: Describe the French and Indian War (1754-1763) as part of the global Seven Years' War
Explain how British victory gave Britain control of North America east of the Mississippi
Analyze Britain's war debt and decision to tax colonies to help pay for it
Describe the Proclamation of 1763 prohibiting colonial settlement west of the Appalachians and colonial anger about it

sub_topics.name: Taxation Without Representation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding colonial resistance to British taxation.
example_tasks: Explain the colonial slogan 'No taxation without representation' and what it meant
Describe the Sugar Act (1764) and Stamp Act (1765) as early attempts to tax colonies
Analyze colonial argument that only their own assemblies could tax them, not distant Parliament
Describe colonial protests including boycotts, petitions, and the Stamp Act Congress
Explain the Townshend Acts (1767) and continued colonial resistance

sub_topics.name: Escalating Conflicts and Violence
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about events that pushed colonies toward rebellion.
example_tasks: Describe the Boston Massacre (1770) and how it was used as propaganda against Britain
Explain the Boston Tea Party (1773) as protest against the Tea Act
Analyze the Intolerable Acts (1774) as British punishment of Massachusetts
Describe the First Continental Congress (1774) as a unified colonial response
Evaluate how each British action provoked stronger colonial reaction

sub_topics.name: The Revolutionary War
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the military conflict between Britain and the thirteen colonies.

sub_topics.name: Beginning of the War: Lexington and Concord
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how armed conflict began in Massachusetts.
example_tasks: Describe the battles of Lexington and Concord (April 1775) as the 'shot heard round the world'
Explain British goals of seizing colonial weapons and arresting rebel leaders
Analyze Paul Revere's ride and colonial preparedness through the militia system
Describe the Second Continental Congress's response, including creating the Continental Army

sub_topics.name: Declaration of Independence
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the document that announced American independence.
example_tasks: Explain Thomas Paine's 'Common Sense' (1776) and its argument for independence
Describe Thomas Jefferson as primary author of the Declaration of Independence
Analyze key sections: preamble on natural rights, list of grievances against George III, declaration of independence
Identify Enlightenment ideas in the Declaration, particularly from John Locke
Evaluate the Declaration's statement that 'all men are created equal' given existence of slavery
Explain the significance of July 4, 1776, as the date of American independence

sub_topics.name: Major Battles and Campaigns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding key military events of the war.
example_tasks: Describe early American defeats and Washington's surprise victories at Trenton and Princeton
Explain the significance of the Battle of Saratoga (1777) as a turning point
Analyze the harsh winter at Valley Forge (1777-1778) and the Continental Army's survival
Describe the final British defeat at Yorktown (1781)
Create a timeline of major battles showing the progression of the war

sub_topics.name: Challenges and Advantages of Both Sides
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing strengths and weaknesses of American and British forces.
example_tasks: Compare British advantages (professional army, navy, wealth) to American advantages (fighting on home territory, motivation, knowledge of terrain)
Explain American disadvantages: shortage of supplies, untrained troops, weak central authority
Analyze George Washington's leadership in holding the army together despite defeats
Describe the role of foreign allies, especially France, in American victory
Evaluate why Britain ultimately failed despite superior military power

sub_topics.name: Treaty of Paris (1783)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the war ended and what America gained.
example_tasks: Describe the terms of the Treaty of Paris recognizing American independence
Explain the new boundaries of the United States extending to the Mississippi River
Analyze British agreement to remove troops and return property
Evaluate the generous terms America received, partly due to European diplomacy

sub_topics.name: Creating a New Nation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining challenges of establishing a government after independence.

sub_topics.name: Articles of Confederation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding America's first constitution and its weaknesses.
example_tasks: Describe the Articles of Confederation as a loose alliance of independent states
Explain weaknesses: no executive, no federal courts, no power to tax, unanimous consent for amendments
Analyze problems these weaknesses caused: inability to pay debts, no common currency, difficulty making decisions
Describe Shays' Rebellion (1786-1787) as evidence the Articles were too weak
Evaluate why Americans initially created such a weak national government (fear of tyranny)

sub_topics.name: Constitutional Convention (1787)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the creation of the U.S. Constitution.
example_tasks: Describe the decision to revise but ultimately replace the Articles of Confederation
Explain major compromises: Great Compromise (bicameral legislature), Three-Fifths Compromise (counting enslaved people), Electoral College
Analyze the system of federalism dividing power between national and state governments
Describe checks and balances based on Montesquieu's ideas
Evaluate the Constitutional Convention as a significant achievement in creating a lasting framework

sub_topics.name: Ratification Debate: Federalists vs. Anti-Federalists
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the debate over whether to ratify the Constitution.
example_tasks: Explain Federalist arguments: need for stronger central government, protection of property, prevention of mob rule
Describe Anti-Federalist concerns: Constitution gave too much power to national government, lacked bill of rights, favored elite
Analyze the Federalist Papers by Hamilton, Madison, and Jay as arguments for ratification
Explain how promise of a Bill of Rights helped achieve ratification
Evaluate both sides' concerns as legitimate fears about power and liberty

sub_topics.name: Bill of Rights (1791)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the first ten amendments protecting individual liberties.
example_tasks: Describe why a Bill of Rights was added to satisfy Anti-Federalist concerns
Explain key rights protected: freedom of religion, speech, press, assembly, petition (1st Amendment)
Describe other important amendments: right to bear arms (2nd), protection against unreasonable search (4th), due process (5th), trial rights (6-8)
Analyze the 10th Amendment reserving powers to states and people
Evaluate how the Bill of Rights has protected liberty throughout American history

sub_topics.name: Significance and Limitations of the Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the Revolution's impact and who benefited from independence.

sub_topics.name: Revolutionary Ideals and Their Application
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the gap between revolutionary rhetoric and reality.
example_tasks: Analyze the Declaration's claim that 'all men are created equal' and who was excluded
Describe how women, enslaved people, Native Americans, and propertyless men gained little from independence
Explain how slavery continued despite language about liberty and equality
Evaluate the contradiction between revolutionary ideals and continuing inequality

sub_topics.name: Global Influence of the American Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how the Revolution inspired other movements worldwide.
example_tasks: Describe the American Revolution as the first successful colonial rebellion
Explain how American ideas influenced the French Revolution
Analyze the inspiration American independence provided to Latin American independence movements
Evaluate the Revolution's role in spreading Enlightenment ideals about rights and self-government

name: French Revolution and Napoleonic Era
short_description: Students examine the causes and phases of the French Revolution, the Reign of Terror, Napoleon's rise to power and empire, and the Congress of Vienna's attempt to restore order and balance of power in Europe.

sub_topics.name: Causes of the French Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the social, economic, and political problems that led to revolution in 1789.

sub_topics.name: The Old Regime and Three Estates
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about France's rigid social hierarchy and inequality.
example_tasks: Describe the three estates: First Estate (clergy), Second Estate (nobility), Third Estate (everyone else - 97% of population)
Explain the privileges of the First and Second Estates: exemption from most taxes, special legal rights
Analyze resentment of the Third Estate, especially the bourgeoisie (middle class), over inequality
Compare the wealth and power of different groups within the Third Estate
Evaluate how the estate system created fundamental unfairness in French society

sub_topics.name: Economic Problems and Financial Crisis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding France's debt crisis and failed attempts at reform.
example_tasks: Describe France's massive debt from wars, including support for the American Revolution
Explain how the tax system placed burdens on the Third Estate while nobles and clergy paid little
Analyze Louis XVI's failed attempts to tax the nobility and their resistance
Describe the calling of the Estates-General in 1789 as a desperate measure to solve the crisis
Evaluate how financial problems exposed deeper issues of political power and inequality

sub_topics.name: Influence of Enlightenment Ideas
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how Enlightenment philosophy inspired demands for change.
example_tasks: Explain how Enlightenment ideas about natural rights and popular sovereignty challenged absolute monarchy
Describe how the success of the American Revolution inspired French reformers
Analyze the spread of revolutionary ideas through books, pamphlets, and salons
Evaluate the role of Enlightenment thinkers like Rousseau and Voltaire in shaping revolutionary thought

sub_topics.name: Phases of the French Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the Revolution's progression from moderate reform to radical violence.

sub_topics.name: Moderate Phase: National Assembly (1789-1791)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding early revolutionary reforms and the constitutional monarchy.
example_tasks: Describe the Tennis Court Oath when Third Estate representatives vowed to create a constitution
Explain the storming of the Bastille (July 14, 1789) as a symbolic revolutionary moment
Analyze the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen and its Enlightenment principles
Describe the abolition of feudalism and end of special privileges for nobles and clergy
Explain the Constitution of 1791 establishing a limited constitutional monarchy
Evaluate the Women's March on Versailles and women's participation in the Revolution

sub_topics.name: Radical Phase: The Republic and Reign of Terror (1792-1794)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the Revolution's violent turn and execution of the king.
example_tasks: Describe the overthrow of the monarchy and establishment of the French Republic in 1792
Explain the trial and execution of Louis XVI in January 1793
Analyze the rise of the radical Jacobins led by Maximilien Robespierre
Describe the Reign of Terror: mass executions by guillotine, suppression of dissent, de-Christianization
Explain the Committee of Public Safety and its dictatorial powers
Analyze how fear of counter-revolution and foreign invasion radicalized the Revolution
Describe the execution of Robespierre in July 1794 (Thermidorian Reaction) ending the Terror

sub_topics.name: The Directory (1795-1799)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the weak government that followed the Terror.
example_tasks: Describe the Directory as a five-man executive attempting to restore stability
Explain problems facing the Directory: economic crisis, political instability, corruption
Analyze continued conflicts between royalists wanting monarchy and radicals wanting more reform
Evaluate how the Directory's weakness created opportunity for military takeover

sub_topics.name: Napoleon Bonaparte's Rise to Power
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how a military general became Emperor of France.

sub_topics.name: Napoleon's Military Career and Popularity
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how military victories made Napoleon a national hero.
example_tasks: Describe Napoleon's successful military campaigns in Italy and Egypt
Explain how military success and personal charisma made Napoleon popular
Analyze Napoleon's political skills and ability to manipulate public opinion
Evaluate how French desire for stability after years of chaos helped Napoleon

sub_topics.name: Coup d'État and The Consulate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Napoleon's seizure of power in 1799.
example_tasks: Describe the coup of 18 Brumaire (November 1799) that overthrew the Directory
Explain Napoleon's position as First Consul with near-dictatorial powers
Analyze the Constitution of 1800 that gave appearance of democracy while concentrating power
Describe domestic reforms: Napoleonic Code, Concordat with Catholic Church, public education, Bank of France
Evaluate whether Napoleon preserved revolutionary gains or betrayed revolutionary ideals

sub_topics.name: Napoleon Crowns Himself Emperor
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Napoleon's transformation from consul to emperor.
example_tasks: Describe Napoleon's coronation as Emperor in 1804 and his crowning of himself
Explain how Napoleon established a new nobility and imperial court
Analyze the plebiscites (votes) Napoleon used to legitimize his power
Evaluate how far France had traveled from 1789's ideals of liberty and equality

sub_topics.name: Napoleon's Empire and Wars
sub_topics.short_description: Examining Napoleon's conquest of most of Europe and eventual defeat.

sub_topics.name: Napoleon's Military Campaigns and Empire
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the extent of French domination of Europe.
example_tasks: Describe Napoleon's major military victories: Austerlitz, Jena, Wagram
Explain the extent of the French Empire by 1810, controlling most of continental Europe
Analyze Napoleon's placement of family members as rulers of conquered territories
Describe the Continental System attempting to blockade Britain economically
Evaluate Napoleon's military genius and innovative tactics

sub_topics.name: Napoleonic Code and Reforms
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Napoleon's lasting legal and administrative reforms.
example_tasks: Describe the Napoleonic Code as comprehensive legal system based on Enlightenment principles
Explain key features: equality before the law, religious toleration, property rights, career open to talent
Analyze limitations: reinforced patriarchal authority, limited women's rights, restored slavery in colonies
Evaluate the Code's lasting influence as it spread across Europe and Latin America

sub_topics.name: Resistance and Rise of Nationalism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Napoleon's conquests sparked nationalist movements.
example_tasks: Explain how French occupation created resentment and nationalist reactions in conquered territories
Describe guerrilla warfare in Spain against French occupation
Analyze how Napoleon inadvertently spread revolutionary and nationalist ideas across Europe
Evaluate the awakening of national consciousness in Germany, Italy, and other regions

sub_topics.name: Napoleon's Downfall
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the disasters that ended Napoleon's empire.
example_tasks: Describe the disastrous invasion of Russia in 1812 and loss of most of the Grand Army
Explain the Battle of Leipzig (1813) where allied forces defeated Napoleon
Analyze Napoleon's first abdication and exile to Elba in 1814
Describe the Hundred Days: Napoleon's return, final defeat at Waterloo (1815), and exile to St. Helena
Evaluate factors in Napoleon's defeat: overextension, nationalism, coalition of enemies

sub_topics.name: Congress of Vienna and Restoration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the attempt to restore stability and prevent future revolutions.

sub_topics.name: The Congress of Vienna (1814-1815)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the peace settlement after Napoleon's defeat.
example_tasks: Describe the major powers at Vienna: Austria, Prussia, Russia, Britain, France
Explain the role of Austrian minister Metternich in shaping the settlement
Analyze the principle of legitimacy: restoring legitimate monarchs to their thrones
Describe territorial changes creating a balance of power to prevent future French aggression
Evaluate whether the Congress succeeded in creating lasting peace

sub_topics.name: Conservative Reaction and Holy Alliance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding attempts to suppress revolutionary and liberal movements.
example_tasks: Explain conservatism's emphasis on tradition, order, and gradual change versus revolution
Describe the Holy Alliance and Concert of Europe as systems to maintain the Vienna settlement
Analyze Metternich's use of censorship and repression to prevent liberal and nationalist movements
Evaluate how the Congress of Vienna temporarily suppressed but couldn't eliminate demands for change

sub_topics.name: Legacy of the French Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the Revolution's lasting impact on Europe and the world.
example_tasks: Evaluate the Revolution's success in ending absolute monarchy and noble privilege in France
Describe the spread of revolutionary ideals: nationalism, liberalism, popular sovereignty
Analyze how the Revolution inspired future democratic and nationalist movements
Compare revolutionary ideals to actual outcomes, including violence and dictatorship
Evaluate historians' debates about whether the Revolution's benefits outweighed its costs

name: Latin American Independence Movements
short_description: Students examine the struggles for independence across Latin America, analyzing the roles of key leaders like Simón Bolívar and José de San Martín, and the challenges facing newly independent nations.

sub_topics.name: Causes of Latin American Independence Movements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why Spanish and Portuguese colonies sought independence.

sub_topics.name: Social and Racial Hierarchies
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about colonial social structures that created resentment.
example_tasks: Describe the social hierarchy: peninsulares at top, then creoles, mestizos, mulattoes, indigenous peoples, enslaved Africans
Explain creole resentment despite being wealthy - excluded from top government positions reserved for peninsulares
Analyze how the vast majority of the population (indigenous, mixed-race, enslaved) had few rights
Evaluate how social inequality created tensions that independence movements could exploit

sub_topics.name: Influence of Enlightenment and Other Revolutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how ideas and examples inspired independence movements.
example_tasks: Explain how Enlightenment ideas about natural rights and self-government spread to Latin America
Describe the inspiration of the American Revolution as successful colonial independence
Analyze how the French Revolution and Haitian Revolution demonstrated possibility of overthrowing existing order
Evaluate the role of educated creoles in reading and spreading revolutionary ideas

sub_topics.name: Napoleonic Wars Create Opportunity
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how Napoleon's conquest of Spain weakened colonial control.
example_tasks: Describe how Napoleon's invasion of Spain (1808) created a power vacuum
Explain how colonial elites initially claimed loyalty to the Spanish king while establishing self-government
Analyze how prolonged instability in Spain gave colonies time to organize independence movements
Evaluate the timing: why independence movements succeeded in early 1800s but not earlier

sub_topics.name: Major Independence Movements and Leaders
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the struggles in different regions of Latin America.

sub_topics.name: Haitian Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the only successful slave revolution in history.
example_tasks: Describe Haiti (Saint-Domingue) as France's wealthiest colony based on sugar and slavery
Explain Toussaint L'Ouverture's leadership of the slave rebellion beginning in 1791
Analyze the revolution's progression through conflicts with France, Spain, and Britain
Describe Haiti's declaration of independence in 1804 as the first independent nation in Latin America
Evaluate the Haitian Revolution's significance as a successful slave revolt and its limited influence due to fear

sub_topics.name: Mexican Independence
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Mexico's path to independence through popular and elite movements.
example_tasks: Describe Father Miguel Hidalgo's Grito de Dolores (1810) calling for independence and social reform
Explain the popular uprising of indigenous and mestizo peoples fighting for land reform
Analyze why creole elites initially opposed Hidalgo's movement due to its radical social goals
Describe how conservative creoles under Agustín de Iturbide achieved independence (1821) to prevent social change
Evaluate Mexico's achievement of independence but failure to address social inequality

sub_topics.name: Simón Bolívar and Northern South America
sub_topics.short_description: Examining 'The Liberator' and his campaigns for independence.
example_tasks: Describe Simón Bolívar's background as wealthy Venezuelan creole inspired by Enlightenment ideals
Explain Bolívar's military campaigns liberating Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia
Analyze Bolívar's dream of a united Gran Colombia and why it failed
Describe Bolívar's disillusionment late in life as new nations fell into dictatorship and chaos
Evaluate Bolívar's legacy as 'The Liberator' of South America

sub_topics.name: José de San Martín and Southern South America
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about independence in Argentina, Chile, and Peru.
example_tasks: Describe José de San Martín's leadership of Argentine independence
Explain his bold strategy of crossing the Andes to liberate Chile
Analyze San Martín's cooperation with Bolívar in liberating Peru
Describe San Martín's mysterious withdrawal from public life after meeting with Bolívar
Compare San Martín's and Bolívar's approaches and personalities

sub_topics.name: Brazilian Independence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Brazil's unique peaceful transition from Portuguese colony to independent empire.
example_tasks: Describe how the Portuguese royal family fled to Brazil during Napoleonic Wars
Explain Prince Pedro's declaration of Brazilian independence in 1822
Analyze why Brazilian independence was relatively peaceful compared to Spanish America
Describe Brazil's maintenance of monarchy (empire) until 1889 while Spanish America became republics
Evaluate factors making Brazil's path to independence unique

sub_topics.name: Challenges Facing New Latin American Nations
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the difficulties of establishing stable governments and economies.

sub_topics.name: Political Instability and Caudillos
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the pattern of military strongmen and frequent coups.
example_tasks: Define caudillo as a military strongman who ruled through personal power rather than institutions
Explain why new nations lacked experience with democratic self-government
Analyze conflicts between liberal and conservative factions over church power, federalism, and social reform
Describe the cycle of constitutions, coups, and dictatorships in many countries
Evaluate why political stability proved so difficult to achieve

sub_topics.name: Economic Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about economic difficulties facing newly independent nations.
example_tasks: Describe damage from years of warfare: destroyed infrastructure, disrupted trade, depopulation
Explain continued economic dependence on exporting raw materials to Europe
Analyze how wars created large debts and financial instability
Evaluate why political instability discouraged economic development and investment

sub_topics.name: Limited Social Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how independence changed little for most people.
example_tasks: Analyze how creole elites replaced peninsulares but social hierarchies remained largely unchanged
Describe continued oppression of indigenous peoples and people of African descent
Explain that most independence movements were led by elites seeking political power, not social revolution
Evaluate the gap between revolutionary rhetoric about equality and continued social inequality
Compare Latin American independence to other revolutions in terms of social transformation

name: Industrial Revolution
short_description: Students examine the transformation from agricultural to industrial economies, technological innovations, urbanization, changing working conditions, and the social and environmental consequences of industrialization.

sub_topics.name: Origins and Causes of the Industrial Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why the Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the late 1700s.

sub_topics.name: Agricultural Revolution as Foundation
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how improved farming created conditions for industrialization.
example_tasks: Describe innovations in farming: crop rotation, selective breeding, new tools like the seed drill
Explain how enclosure movement consolidated small farms into larger, more efficient estates
Analyze how agricultural improvements increased food production and population
Evaluate how fewer farmers were needed, creating labor available for factory work

sub_topics.name: Why Britain First?
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding unique conditions that gave Britain advantages.
example_tasks: Describe Britain's natural resources: abundant coal and iron ore deposits
Explain Britain's extensive colonial empire providing raw materials and markets
Analyze political stability, strong banking system, and culture supporting entrepreneurship
Describe Britain's transportation advantages: rivers, canals, and as an island nation
Evaluate how multiple factors combined to make Britain the birthplace of industrialization

sub_topics.name: Technological Innovations and Industries
sub_topics.short_description: Examining key inventions that transformed production and transportation.

sub_topics.name: Textile Industry Innovations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about inventions that revolutionized cloth production.
example_tasks: Describe the spinning jenny, water frame, and spinning mule increasing yarn production
Explain the power loom mechanizing weaving
Analyze how textile innovations created demand for cotton from American South and British colonies
Evaluate textiles as the leading industry of the early Industrial Revolution
Compare hand production to factory production in terms of speed and efficiency

sub_topics.name: Steam Engine and Power Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how steam power transformed manufacturing and transportation.
example_tasks: Describe James Watt's improvements to the steam engine in the 1760s-1770s
Explain how steam power freed factories from needing to be located near water
Analyze applications of steam power in textile mills, mining, and iron production
Evaluate the steam engine as the most important single invention of the Industrial Revolution

sub_topics.name: Iron and Steel Production
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about advances in metallurgy that provided materials for machines and construction.
example_tasks: Describe new methods of iron production using coal (coke) instead of charcoal
Explain the Bessemer process (1850s) for mass-producing steel
Analyze how stronger, cheaper iron and steel enabled building of machines, railroads, and bridges
Evaluate iron and steel as fundamental to industrial infrastructure

sub_topics.name: Transportation Revolution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining innovations in moving goods and people.
example_tasks: Describe the development of railroads and George Stephenson's Rocket locomotive (1829)
Explain how railroads reduced transportation costs and time dramatically
Analyze Robert Fulton's steamboat and its impact on river and ocean transport
Evaluate how improved transportation created national and international markets
Create a timeline showing progression from canals to railroads to steamships

sub_topics.name: Communication Innovations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about technologies that speeded communication.
example_tasks: Describe Samuel Morse's telegraph (1840s) and its use of electrical signals
Explain how the telegraph enabled near-instantaneous long-distance communication
Analyze the impact of faster communication on business, journalism, and government
Evaluate how communication and transportation innovations worked together to shrink distances

sub_topics.name: The Factory System and Working Conditions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how industrialization changed where and how people worked.

sub_topics.name: Rise of the Factory System
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the shift from home production to centralized factories.
example_tasks: Compare cottage industry (home-based production) to factory system (centralized production with machines)
Explain advantages of factories: specialization, efficiency, economies of scale
Describe how factories required workers to maintain machines' pace rather than their own
Analyze how factory discipline differed from agricultural work rhythms

sub_topics.name: Working Conditions in Factories and Mines
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the harsh realities of industrial labor.
example_tasks: Describe typical working conditions: 12-16 hour days, six days per week, dangerous machinery, poor ventilation
Explain the use of child labor in factories and mines, often in the most dangerous jobs
Analyze specific hazards in textile mills, coal mines, and iron works
Describe testimony from parliamentary investigations documenting abusive conditions
Evaluate the human cost of rapid industrialization

sub_topics.name: Child Labor
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the widespread employment of children in industrial work.
example_tasks: Describe how children as young as 5-6 worked in factories and mines
Explain economic reasons families sent children to work: low wages required multiple incomes
Analyze specific jobs children performed: crawling in mine tunnels, operating textile machines, chimney sweeping
