Describe gradual reform through Factory Acts limiting child labor
Evaluate changing attitudes about childhood and education during this period

sub_topics.name: Urbanization and Social Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the massive migration from countryside to cities and resulting problems.

sub_topics.name: Rapid Urban Growth
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the dramatic increase in city populations.
example_tasks: Describe the massive population growth of industrial cities like Manchester, Birmingham, and London
Explain push factors (enclosure, agricultural changes) and pull factors (factory jobs) causing rural-urban migration
Analyze the speed of urban growth overwhelming existing infrastructure
Create graphs showing population changes in major industrial cities 1750-1850

sub_topics.name: Problems of Industrial Cities
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the challenges of rapid, unplanned urbanization.
example_tasks: Describe overcrowded, poorly built housing in working-class neighborhoods
Explain lack of sanitation: no running water, primitive sewage, accumulation of waste
Analyze disease outbreaks including cholera epidemics due to contaminated water
Describe air and water pollution from factories
Evaluate life expectancy differences between wealthy and poor urban neighborhoods

sub_topics.name: Emergence of New Social Classes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how industrialization created industrial middle class and working class.
example_tasks: Describe the industrial middle class (bourgeoisie): factory owners, merchants, professionals
Explain the industrial working class (proletariat): factory workers with few skills and low wages
Analyze class tensions between wealthy factory owners and poor workers
Compare social mobility in industrial society to traditional agricultural society
Evaluate Karl Marx's analysis of class conflict between bourgeoisie and proletariat

sub_topics.name: Responses to Industrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how people and governments reacted to industrial problems.

sub_topics.name: Labor Unions and Worker Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about workers' collective action to improve conditions.
example_tasks: Describe early attempts to form labor unions despite laws prohibiting them
Explain tactics workers used: strikes, collective bargaining, political action
Analyze government and business resistance to unions
Describe gradual legalization and acceptance of unions in later 19th century
Evaluate unions' role in achieving better wages, hours, and working conditions

sub_topics.name: Reform Movements and Factory Legislation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding government intervention to address industrial abuses.
example_tasks: Describe British Factory Acts gradually limiting working hours and child labor
Explain public health reforms: sanitation systems, clean water, housing regulations
Analyze the role of reformers documenting abuses and demanding change
Evaluate the shift from laissez-faire (no government intervention) to regulated capitalism

sub_topics.name: Luddites and Machine Breaking
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about violent resistance to new technology.
example_tasks: Describe the Luddite movement of British textile workers destroying machines (1811-1816)
Explain Luddite fears that machines would eliminate their jobs and skills
Analyze government's harsh response: making machine-breaking a capital offense
Evaluate whether Luddites were simply opposing progress or defending their livelihoods

sub_topics.name: Socialist and Communist Responses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding radical critiques of industrial capitalism.
example_tasks: Describe utopian socialists like Robert Owen who created model communities
Explain Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels's 'Communist Manifesto' (1848) calling for workers to overthrow capitalism
Analyze Marx's critique of capitalism: exploitation of workers, alienation, class struggle
Compare utopian socialism (reform capitalism) to Marxism (revolutionary overthrow)
Evaluate influence of socialist thought on later labor movements and political parties

sub_topics.name: Spread of Industrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how industrialization spread from Britain to other regions.

sub_topics.name: Industrialization in Continental Europe
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about industrial development in Belgium, France, Germany, and other European nations.
example_tasks: Describe Belgium as the first continental nation to industrialize, borrowing British technology
Explain Germany's rapid industrialization in late 19th century, eventually surpassing Britain
Analyze why France industrialized more slowly due to political instability and different economic structure
Compare government's role in promoting industrialization across different nations

sub_topics.name: American Industrialization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the United States' industrial development.
example_tasks: Describe American advantages: vast natural resources, growing population, political stability
Explain the role of railroads in linking the continent and creating national markets
Analyze American innovations including interchangeable parts and assembly line production
Evaluate how American industrialization differed from British model

sub_topics.name: Uneven Global Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why some regions industrialized while others remained agricultural.
example_tasks: Analyze factors needed for industrialization: capital, resources, labor, technology, political stability
Explain why Latin America, Africa, and much of Asia remained primarily agricultural
Describe the emerging gap between industrialized and non-industrialized regions
Evaluate how industrialization created or widened global inequalities

name: Imperialism and Colonialism in the 19th Century
short_description: Students analyze the European and American expansion and colonization of Africa, Asia, and the Pacific, examining economic and political motivations, the ideology of the 'civilizing mission,' resistance movements, and the lasting impacts of imperialism.

sub_topics.name: Causes of the New Imperialism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why industrialized nations sought colonies in the late 19th century.

sub_topics.name: Economic Motivations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about industrial nations' need for resources and markets.
example_tasks: Explain the need for raw materials (rubber, oil, minerals, cotton) to supply industrial production
Describe the search for new markets to sell manufactured goods
Analyze the desire for profitable investment opportunities for surplus capital
Evaluate how economic competition between industrial powers drove imperial expansion

sub_topics.name: Political and Strategic Motivations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding power politics and national prestige as drivers of imperialism.
example_tasks: Describe nationalism and competition for national glory and prestige
Explain strategic interests: naval bases, coaling stations, protecting trade routes
Analyze the concept of 'balance of power' and fear of rivals gaining advantages
Evaluate how military technology (steamships, railways, machine guns) made conquest easier

sub_topics.name: Ideological Justifications
sub_topics.short_description: Examining racist and paternalistic ideas used to justify imperialism.
example_tasks: Describe Social Darwinism and its misapplication to justify European superiority
Explain the 'White Man's Burden' concept and the supposed duty to 'civilize' others
Analyze religious motivations: spreading Christianity to 'heathen' peoples
Evaluate Rudyard Kipling's poem 'The White Man's Burden' as expression of imperialist ideology
Critique the racism underlying claims of European superiority and the 'civilizing mission'

sub_topics.name: The Scramble for Africa
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the rapid European colonization of nearly all of Africa.

sub_topics.name: Africa Before the Scramble
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that in 1880, Europeans controlled only small coastal areas of Africa.
example_tasks: Describe the limited European presence in Africa before 1880: coastal trading posts
Explain why Europeans had not penetrated the interior: disease, African resistance, lack of economic incentive
Analyze how technological changes (quinine, steamships, railroads, repeating rifles) enabled conquest
Evaluate Africa's diverse political organizations: kingdoms, empires, chiefdoms, stateless societies

sub_topics.name: Berlin Conference (1884-1885)
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about European powers dividing Africa among themselves.
example_tasks: Describe the Berlin Conference where European powers set rules for claiming African territory
Explain that no African representatives were present at this conference about their continent
Analyze principles established: effective occupation, notification of claims, free trade
Evaluate how arbitrary borders divided ethnic groups and combined rival groups, causing lasting problems

sub_topics.name: Methods of European Conquest
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Europeans achieved military domination.
example_tasks: Describe technological advantages: machine guns (Maxim gun), repeating rifles, artillery
Explain tactics of divide and rule: exploiting African rivalries, recruiting African soldiers
Analyze the role of European diseases decimating some African populations
Describe specific conquests showing European military advantages

sub_topics.name: African Resistance to Colonization
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about African efforts to resist European conquest.
example_tasks: Describe the Zulu resistance under Shaka and later leaders against British conquest
Explain the Ashanti resistance in West Africa against British expansion
Analyze Ethiopia's successful defeat of Italy at the Battle of Adwa (1896), remaining independent
Describe the Maji Maji Rebellion in German East Africa
Evaluate why most resistance ultimately failed but showed African agency and determination

sub_topics.name: Systems of Colonial Rule
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different approaches to governing African colonies.
example_tasks: Compare direct rule (French model: replacing local rulers with French officials) to indirect rule (British model: governing through traditional rulers)
Describe paternalism: treating Africans as children needing European guidance
Explain economic exploitation: forced labor, cash crop production, resource extraction
Analyze how colonial policies disrupted traditional African societies and economies
Evaluate the dual legal systems: one for Europeans, another for Africans

sub_topics.name: Imperialism in Asia
sub_topics.short_description: Examining European and American expansion in Asia and Asian responses.

sub_topics.name: British India and the Raj
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the jewel of the British Empire.
example_tasks: Describe how the British East India Company gradually gained control of India
Explain the Sepoy Mutiny/Indian Rebellion of 1857 and its causes
Analyze the establishment of direct British rule (the Raj) after 1858
Describe economic exploitation: textile industry destroyed, raw materials extracted, Indian market for British goods
Evaluate both negative impacts (economic exploitation, famines, racism) and British claims of positive modernization

sub_topics.name: Imperialism in China
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Western penetration of China through unequal treaties.
example_tasks: Describe the Opium Wars (1839-1842, 1856-1860) forcing China to open to British trade
Explain the Treaty of Nanjing and the system of unequal treaties and spheres of influence
Analyze the Taiping Rebellion (1850-1864) as both internal crisis and response to Western intrusion
Describe the Boxer Rebellion (1899-1901) as violent anti-foreign, anti-Christian uprising
Evaluate China's semi-colonization: never fully colonized but carved into spheres of influence

sub_topics.name: Japan's Modernization and Imperial Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about Japan's unique response to Western imperialism.
example_tasks: Describe Commodore Perry's 1853 expedition forcing Japan to open to trade
Explain the Meiji Restoration (1868) and Japan's rapid modernization program
Analyze Japan's strategy: 'learn from the West to resist the West'
Describe Japan's own imperial expansion: defeating China (1895), defeating Russia (1905), annexing Korea (1910)
Evaluate Japan as the only Asian nation to successfully modernize and become an imperial power

sub_topics.name: Southeast Asia and the Pacific
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding colonization of Southeast Asia and Pacific islands.
example_tasks: Describe British control of Burma and Malaya, French control of Indochina, Dutch control of Indonesia
Explain American acquisition of the Philippines after Spanish-American War (1898)
Analyze different colonial economies: plantation agriculture, resource extraction, trade
Describe only Siam (Thailand) maintaining independence through skillful diplomacy

sub_topics.name: Impact of Imperialism
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the effects of colonialism on colonized peoples and imperial powers.

sub_topics.name: Economic Impact on Colonies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how colonial economies were structured to benefit imperial powers.
example_tasks: Describe the extraction of raw materials while preventing local industrial development
Explain how colonies were forced to buy manufactured goods from the colonizing country
Analyze the introduction of cash crop agriculture and its effects on food security
Evaluate long-term economic dependency created by colonial economic structures

sub_topics.name: Social and Cultural Impact
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about disruption of traditional societies and cultural changes.
example_tasks: Describe the imposition of European languages, education systems, and laws
Explain missionary activities and conversion to Christianity
Analyze racism and segregation in colonial societies
Evaluate the disruption of traditional authority structures and social hierarchies
Describe the emergence of Western-educated elite who would later lead independence movements

sub_topics.name: Debating the Legacy of Imperialism
sub_topics.short_description: Examining different perspectives on imperialism's effects.
example_tasks: Analyze imperialist claims of benefits: railroads, schools, hospitals, modern technology, ending slavery
Describe anti-imperialist critique: exploitation, cultural destruction, violence, racism, underdevelopment
Evaluate the concept of the 'dual mandate': developing colonies while benefiting imperial power
Compare colonial apologists' views to modern historians' assessments
Formulate your own evidence-based judgment about imperialism's net impact

sub_topics.name: Early Anti-Colonial Resistance and Nationalism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how imperialism sparked nationalist movements.
example_tasks: Describe the emergence of nationalist movements demanding independence or self-rule
Explain the role of Western-educated elites in articulating nationalist demands
Analyze how imperialism ironically fostered national consciousness by uniting diverse groups against foreign rule
Evaluate early nationalist organizations like Indian National Congress (1885)

name: Reform Movements of the 19th Century
short_description: Students examine major social reform movements including abolition of slavery, women's rights, education reform, labor rights, and other efforts to address social problems in industrial societies.

sub_topics.name: Abolition of Slavery
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the movement to end slavery in the Americas and globally.

sub_topics.name: Arguments Against Slavery
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about moral, religious, and political cases for abolition.
example_tasks: Describe religious arguments: slavery contradicts Christian teaching about human dignity
Explain Enlightenment arguments based on natural rights and human equality
Analyze economic arguments: free labor more efficient than slave labor
Evaluate powerful slave narratives and testimonies exposing slavery's brutality

sub_topics.name: British Abolition Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Britain ended slavery in its empire.
example_tasks: Describe William Wilberforce and other abolitionists' long campaign in Parliament
Explain the 1807 ban on the slave trade and 1833 abolition of slavery in British Empire
Analyze tactics: petitions, boycotts, slave narratives, parliamentary debate
Evaluate Britain's subsequent role in suppressing the international slave trade

sub_topics.name: Abolition in the United States
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the longer, more conflicted American path to abolition.
example_tasks: Describe the growing abolitionist movement: William Lloyd Garrison, Frederick Douglass, Harriet Tubman
Explain sectional conflict between free North and slave South
Analyze the role of the Civil War (1861-1865) in ending slavery
Describe the Emancipation Proclamation (1863) and 13th Amendment (1865)
Evaluate the difference between legal freedom and actual equality after emancipation

sub_topics.name: Abolition in Latin America and Elsewhere
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the gradual end of slavery across the Americas.
example_tasks: Describe early abolition in Haiti after the revolution (1804)
Explain gradual abolition in Spanish American republics during independence era
Analyze Brazil as last Western nation to abolish slavery (1888)
Evaluate the global trend toward abolition despite resistance from slave-owning interests

sub_topics.name: Women's Rights Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the struggle for women's political, legal, and economic equality.

sub_topics.name: Legal and Social Restrictions on Women
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding women's subordinate status in 19th century society.
example_tasks: Describe legal restrictions: no voting rights, limited property rights, few educational opportunities
Explain the doctrine of 'separate spheres': men in public life, women confined to domestic roles
Analyze economic dependence: limited job opportunities, lower wages for same work
Evaluate how industrialization changed women's work but maintained inequality

sub_topics.name: Early Feminist Thinkers and Activists
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about pioneers who demanded women's rights.
example_tasks: Describe Mary Wollstonecraft's 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman' (1792) as foundational feminist text
Explain the Seneca Falls Convention (1848) and the Declaration of Sentiments
Analyze arguments for women's rights based on Enlightenment principles of equality
Describe leaders like Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Lucretia Mott, and Susan B. Anthony

sub_topics.name: Women's Suffrage Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the campaign for women's voting rights.
example_tasks: Describe suffragist tactics: petitions, demonstrations, civil disobedience
Explain arguments for and against women's suffrage
Analyze British suffragettes' increasingly militant tactics in early 20th century
Describe gradual achievement of voting rights in different countries (New Zealand 1893, Britain 1918-1928, US 1920)
Evaluate why women's suffrage took so long to achieve despite democratic rhetoric

sub_topics.name: Other Women's Rights Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about demands beyond suffrage.
example_tasks: Describe campaigns for married women's property rights
Explain demands for equal access to education and professions
Analyze the movement for reproductive rights and family planning
Evaluate connections between women's rights and other reform movements

sub_topics.name: Education Reform
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the movement to expand access to public education.

sub_topics.name: Growth of Public Education Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the development of free, compulsory schooling.
example_tasks: Describe the gradual establishment of free public elementary schools
Explain arguments for universal education: informed citizenship, economic development, social mobility
Analyze the expansion of compulsory attendance laws
Evaluate how public education both promoted opportunity and reinforced social hierarchies

sub_topics.name: Education Reformers and Innovations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding new educational philosophies and methods.
example_tasks: Describe Horace Mann's advocacy for common schools in America
Explain innovations in teaching methods and curriculum
Analyze debates about education's purposes: practical skills versus classical learning
Evaluate the gradual increase in literacy rates due to expanded schooling

sub_topics.name: Temperance Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Examining campaigns to reduce or prohibit alcohol consumption.

sub_topics.name: Arguments for Temperance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why reformers targeted alcohol.
example_tasks: Describe concerns about alcohol's effects: domestic violence, poverty, health problems, loss of productivity
Explain religious and moral arguments against drinking
Analyze women's leadership in temperance movement linking alcohol to family welfare
Evaluate temperance as part of broader effort to reform individual morality and behavior

sub_topics.name: Prison and Criminal Justice Reform
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding efforts to make punishment more humane.

sub_topics.name: Goals of Prison Reform
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about changing ideas about punishment.
example_tasks: Describe reform goals: rehabilitation rather than just punishment, ending torture and harsh physical punishment
Explain Enlightenment influence: Cesare Beccaria's arguments against torture and for proportional punishment
Analyze the development of the penitentiary system designed to reform criminals
Evaluate the gap between reform ideals and actual prison conditions

sub_topics.name: Interconnections Among Reform Movements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how different reform causes were related.

sub_topics.name: Common Themes and Activists
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing shared ideas and overlap among movements.
example_tasks: Describe how many reformers participated in multiple movements (abolition, women's rights, temperance)
Explain common themes: expanding democracy, ending oppression, applying Enlightenment ideals
Analyze the role of religious motivations in many reform movements
Evaluate reform movements as responses to problems created by industrialization and urbanization
Compare optimistic belief in progress and perfectibility among 19th century reformers
